questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a fall from a ladder. His partner, who witnessed the incident, reports that he hit his head with subsequent loss of consciousness for several minutes. On arrival, the patient reports a severe headache, feels nauseated, and vomits twice. He does not have any visual changes. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On physical examination, bruising is noted over the left side of the head. The pupils are round, equal and reactive to light. Motor strength in the right lower extremity is 2/5 when compared to 5/5 of the left lower extremity. A non-contrast CT is obtained and reveals an anterior midline shift of 20 mm. Which of the following best describes the intracerebral changes responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Inferior shift of the parahippocampal gyrus
Shift of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri
Inferior shift of the diencephalon and temporal lobes
Shift of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum

questions.solution:
This patient presents with headaches, signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), and lower limb hemiparesis contralateral to the injury, raising concerns for cingulate gyrus herniation secondary to traumatic intracranial bleeding.

Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation is a type of supratentorial herniation in which there is a lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri as a result of traumatic brain injury, intracranial hemorrhage, brain tumor or abscess. This herniation can cause compression of the anterior cerebral artery and infarction of the frontal and parietal lobes, resulting in contralateral leg paralysis. Hydrocephalus may also occur due to obstruction of the foramen of Monro. Clinical features of cingulate herniation are not well defined but may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma. Subfalcine herniation may also be a precursor of other types of herniation (e.g. uncal herniation).  



Option Analysis

❌ Inferior shift of the parahippocampal gyrus  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uncal transtentorial herniation. The uncus is the anterior terminus of the parahippocampal gyrus, located at the innermost part of the temporal lobe. In uncal herniation, the uncus becomes compressed against the tentorium. This displacement may result in compression of the 3rd cranial nerve, the cerebral peduncles, and the posterior cerebral arteries, resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and occipital lobe infarction, respectively.  
✅ Shift of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inferior shift of the diencephalon and temporal lobes  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with central transtentorial herniation, in which there is a displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries), a potentially fatal complication known as Duret hemorrhages.  
❌ Shift of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum  :
Incorrect: Tonsillar herniation, also called downward cerebellar herniation, refers to downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Clinical manifestations include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, and signs of brain stem dysfunction due to compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers.  
❌ Transcalvarial brain herniation  :
Incorrect: External herniation, also known as transcalvarial herniation, refers to herniation of the brain parenchyma through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. The signs and symptoms depend upon the location and size of the herniation. This patient’s skull is intact.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset, severe headache. An hour ago, the patient was cooking dinner when he suddenly experienced a diffuse, excruciating headache. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. The patient appears uncomfortable and in pain, but physical examination is otherwise within normal limits. A non-contrast CT scan is obtained and is noncontributory. A lumbar puncture is subsequently performed and yields straw-colored cerebrospinal fluid, and the patient is admitted to the neurosurgery service for management. On the 4th day of hospitalization, the patient suddenly experiences right hand weakness and difficulty speaking. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s new onset symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with a sudden onset, severe headache, raising concerns for an intracranial process. Although the initial CT was negative, a lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) by demonstrating xanthochromia. Four days later, the patient experiences focal weakness and aphasia, which is concerning for vasospasm of the cerebral vessels.

Vasospasm of the cerebral vessels is a common and devastating complication of SAH that typically occurs after the first 48 hours following the initial bleeding. The presentation of symptoms depends upon the artery affected and the presence of collateral circulation, but patients typically demonstrate focal neurologic deficits consistent with the distribution of the spasming blood vessel. Vasospasm can be avoided by administration of nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker, within the first 48 hours of symptom onset.

Other early complications of SAH include rebleeding, cerebral edema, seizures, hyponatremia, and cardiopulmonary and neuroendocrine dysfunction.  



Option Analysis

❌ Rebleeding:
Incorrect: Rebleeding is a known consequence of subarachnoid hemorrhage; however, this condition typically occurs in the first 24 hours, not after 4 days.  
❌ Ischemic stroke:
Incorrect: While an ischemic stroke is possible, this patient has evidence of a recent subarachnoid hemorrhage – making an alternative complication more likely.  
✅ Vasospasm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cerebral herniation:
Incorrect: Patients with cerebral herniation syndrome present with dilated, asymmetric pupils and the Cushing triad of bradycardia, widened pulse pressure, and irregular respirations.  
❌ Cerebral edema  :
Incorrect: Patients with elevated levels of intracranial pressure secondary to cerebral edema typically present with a decreased level of consciousness and evidence of hydrocephalus rather than focal neurologic deficits.

questions.text: A 28-years-old man comes to the emergency department due to a severe headache of 2-days duration. He endorses an intermittent, pressure-like headache, accompanied by episodes of right arm numbness and weakness. He has not had diplopia, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, or alterations in consciousness. The patient and his spouse were involved in a motorcycle crash one month ago. He has a history of chronic alcohol use. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on imaging of the head?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new onset headache and right sided focal neurologic deficit following subacute/chronic trauma. Given these findings, he is most likely suffering from an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma (SDH), which refers to a secondary episode of bleeding into a preexisting hematoma.

Subdural hematoma refers to bleeding into the space between the dura and arachnoid layers caused by tearing of the bridging veins that connect the surface of the brain to the dural sinuses. SDH can be further classified as acute, subacute, chronic, or acute-on-chronic. On imaging, acute SDH appears as a high-density crescentic collection on head CT due to the high content of hemoglobin, whereas chronic SDH appears as a hypodense crescent-shaped lesion due to the absorption of blood products. Acute-on-chronic lesions will appear as mixed hyper- and hypodense collections. Depending on the severity, treatment may involve conservative management or surgical evacuation.



Option Analysis

❌ Reproduced from: Radiopaedia:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with an acute subdural hematoma, which appears as a crescent-shaped homogeneously hyperdense extra-axial collection on non-contrast CT scan due to the high content of hemoglobin in the clot. However, this patient had an accident one month ago and now presents with a new onset of headache, suggesting an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma.   
❌ Reproduced from: Radiopaedia:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with chronic subdural hematoma, which appears as a crescent-shaped homogeneously hyperdense extra-axial collection on non-contrast CT scan due to blood products absorption. However, this patient's neurologic deficits are right sided, suggesting pathology over the left motor homunculus.   
✅ Retrieved from: Radiopaedia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retrieved from: Radiopaedia:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with epidural hematoma, which is most commonly caused by rupture of the middle meningeal artery from trauma near the temporal area. Patients often present with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid deterioration and death if left untreated. On a non-contrast head CT, a lens-shaped lesion is seen. This patient had a more insidious presentation, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which typically occurs due to middle cerebral artery rupture. It is often seen in patients with pre-existing saccular aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations. On head CT, it appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space, most commonly around the Circle of Willis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician for evaluation of personality changes. Over the past two months, he has become progressively irritable and apathetic. His partner also notes fluctuations in his behavior stating, “He has good and bad days.” His medical history includes hypertension and atrial fibrillation, for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide and warfarin. The patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears indifferent and responds vaguely to questions. The patient undergoes a non-contrast CT brain as demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This older patient presents with a progressive decline in function and associated personality changes, raising concern for an underlying toxic, metabolic, or traumatic cause. The CT-brain demonstrates a crescent-shaped lesion, confirming the diagnosis of subdural hematoma (SDH).

SDH refers to bleeding into the space between the dura and arachnoid layers induced by tearing of the bridging veins. These veins connect the surface of the brain to the dural sinuses. SDH can be further classified as acute, subacute, chronic, or acute on chronic. In acute subdural hematoma formation, up to 50% of patients experience coma, while others may present with a “lucid interval” before deterioration from the expanding hematoma. In contrast, a chronic SDH is marked by an insidious onset of headaches, fluctuations in cognitive function, apathy, somnolence, and occasional seizures, which become evident weeks following the initial insult.

Patients at risk for SDH include elderly patients (due to underlying cerebral atrophy), individuals with chronic alcohol use, and those with previous traumatic brain injury. Other risk factors include the use of antithrombotic agents (e.g. aspirin, warfarin). On imaging, acute SDH appears as a high-density crescentic collection on head CT, while chronic SDH appears as a hypodense crescent-shaped lesion. Depending on the severity, treatment involves surgical evacuation or conservative management.



Option Analysis

❌ Epidural hematoma:
Incorrect: The majority of cases of epidural hematoma are caused by severe head trauma during accidents, falls, and assaults. Epidural hematomas are most commonly caused by rupture of the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion. Patients often present with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid deterioration and death if left untreated. On a non-contrast head CT, a lens-shaped lesion is observed. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.
❌ Cerebral contusion:
Incorrect: Cerebral contusion refers to bruising of the brain parenchyma. The edema surrounding the contusion may result in fluctuating levels of consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, or neurologic deterioration. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.  
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage occurs secondary to rupture of a saccular aneurysm or an arteriovenous malformation. Patients often complain of the “worst headache of my life.” On head CT,  SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.  
✅ Subdural hematoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect: Vascular dementia refers to a stepwise decline in cognitive function and memory impairment caused by multiple arterial infarcts and/or chronic ischemia. On imaging, multiple cortical and/or subcortical infarcts are observed. This patient’s imaging and timeline are more consistent with subdural hematoma.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an acute-onset, severe headache. The patient was preparing dinner when she suddenly lost consciousness and fell to the floor. Upon awakening, the patient endorsed “the worst headache of my life.” Her medical history is notable for a ventricular septal defect repaired during childhood. She is nauseated and has vomited twice. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.1°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears in acute distress due to pain. Her pupils are equal and reactive to light. A non-contrast CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?  


Retrieved from: ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This previously healthy woman presents with a sudden onset, severe headache and loss of consciousness. The CT demonstrates a hyperdense collection within the Circle of Willis, confirming the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

SAH refers to the pooling of blood in the subarachnoid space. Major causes include rupture of a pre-existing saccular “berry” aneurysm (most common) or, less commonly, bleeding from an arteriovenous malformation, tumor or traumatic injury. Patients often present with the “worst headache of my life” (thunderclap headache) or a headache that reaches maximum intensity within seconds to minutes.

Common findings include a brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain/stiffness, and focal neurologic deficits. Diagnosis is performed with a non-contrast CT-brain that will reveal blood in the subarachnoid space. If inconclusive, lumbar puncture is indicated, which may show bloody or yellow cerebrospinal fluid called xanthochromia (as a result of the broken down blood products in the CSF). Treatment of SAH involves surgical clipping or coiling of the ruptured aneurysm.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypertensive encephalopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertensive encephalopathy refers to the altered mentation observed in patients with a hypertensive emergency. Other manifestations of hypertensive emergency include stroke, retinal hemorrhages and exudates, papilledema, myocardial infarction, heart failure, kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The presence of a hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis seen on this CT favors another diagnosis.
❌ Intracerebral hemorrhage  :
Incorrect: Intracerebral hemorrhage may present with headache, vomiting, and altered mentation that typically develop when the hemorrhage becomes large enough. Other signs and symptoms depend on the location and size of the bleeding. In contrast to subarachnoid hemorrhage, the symptoms associated with intracerebral hemorrhage typically develop gradually over hours. The presence of a hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis seen on this CT favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Cluster headache:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches are characterized by a severe unilateral headache with associated  autonomic symptoms ipsilateral to the pain. Episodes generally occur at the same time of the day or multiple times per day, lasting 15 minutes to 3 hours. However, CT findings are normal in patients presenting with cluster headaches.  
✅ Berry aneurysm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paradoxical emboli:
Incorrect: Paradoxical embolism refers to a systemic venous embolism that passes to the systemic arterial circulation through an atrioventricular septal defect and lodges in the brain vessels. While this patient did have a ventricular septal defect, it has been repaired, and thus she is no longer at risk of a paradoxical embolism. In addition, embolic events are unlikely to be visualized on a non-contrast CT-brain.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following an altercation at a bar where he was hit over the left side of his head with a bottle. The patient subsequently lost consciousness and spontaneously awakened minutes later. He initially refused medical evaluation, but a few hours later, he began vomiting and agreed to be taken to the hospital. On arrival, the patient suddenly loses consciousness. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 144/40 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient does not respond to painful stimuli. The left pupil is dilated and inferolaterally abducted. A non-contrast CT is obtained and demonstrates a convex lesion with mass effect and downward displacement of the inferior temporal lobe. This patient's clinical presentation is best defined by which of the following injury patterns?

choices.text: Intra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; secondary brain injury
Extra-axial injury; infratentorial; secondary brain injury

questions.solution:
This patient presents with blunt head trauma and classic features of an epidural hematoma including a “lucid interval,” a lens shaped lesion, and signs of impending herniation. The physical examination demonstrates a blown, dilated pupil, indicating uncal herniation secondary to extrinsic compression of cranial nerve III. Lastly, the CT results confirm the diagnosis of an epidural hematoma, which is an extra-axial bleed, with secondary brain herniation.  

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) can be classified as primary (e.g. epidural hematoma) or secondary (e.g. brain herniation), the latter of which occurs due to mass effect and increased intracranial pressure. Another way to classify herniation is with respect to the tentorium: supratentorial herniation (cingulate, a.k.a. subfalcine), central transtentorial herniation, or infratentorial herniation (downward/cerebellar tonsillar herniation or upward cerebellar/transtentorial herniation). Finally, TBI that occurs within the brain parenchyma is classified as intra-axial (e.g. diffuse axonal injury) or extra-axial (e.g., epidural, subdural).  




Option Analysis

❌ Intra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury  :
Incorrect: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is an example of this injury pattern. Patients with DAI often present with deep coma without elevated intracranial pressure. DAI occurs as a result of traumatic shearing forces applied to the brain when the head is rapidly accelerated and/or decelerated affecting the gray-white junction. Another example of intra-axial injury is a focal cerebral contusion. This patient more likely has an extra-axial injury.  
❌ Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; primary brain injury  :
Incorrect: Examples of this injury pattern include epidural, subdural, and subarachnoid hematomas without signs of brain herniation. This patient has imaging and exam findings indicative of herniation, a secondary brain injury.  
✅ Extra-axial injury; supratentorial; secondary brain injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extra-axial injury; infratentorial; secondary brain injury  :
Incorrect: An example of this injury pattern includes downward cerebellar/tonsillar herniation or upward cerebellar/transtentorial herniation from a tumor or hematoma secondary to trauma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with supratentorial herniation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle crash, where she hit her head over the left temporal area with associated loss of consciousness. En route to the hospital, the patient suddenly loses consciousness again. On arrival, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient has swelling, ecchymosis, and crepitus over the left temporal skull. Non-contrast CT is most likely to demonstrate which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis
Hyperdense collection within the basal ganglia
Multiple hyperdense collections at the gray-white junction

questions.solution:
This patient most likely suffered a fracture at the pterion with concomitant middle meningeal artery rupture and epidural hematoma formation. The majority of cases of epidural hematoma occur secondary to head trauma during motor vehicle crashes, falls, and assaults. The most commonly implicated vessel is the middle meningeal artery as it passes under the pterion–the confluence where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones merge. On head CT, epidural bleeding creates a lens-shaped lesion as the collection is bordered by dural attachments at the cranial sutures.

Patients with epidural hematomas often experience a “lucid interval,” which refers to a temporary improvement in consciousness before rapid loss of consciousness and clinical deterioration from the expanding hematoma. Manifestations of epidural hematoma include headaches, drowsiness, confusion, aphasia, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. Additionally, the Cushing triad (bradycardia, hypertension, and respiratory depression) may be observed secondary to elevated intracranial hypertension and brain stem compression. Treatment typically involves an emergency craniotomy and hematoma evacuation to prevent irreversible brain injury and death.



Option Analysis

✅ Biconvex hyperdense lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Crescent-shaped lesion:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a subdural hematoma, which occurs due to rupture of the bridging veins. Subdural hematomas may be acute due to high energy trauma (e.g. motor vehicle accident) or chronic from low energy trauma (e.g., brain atrophy, chronic alcohol use). However, trauma to the pterion (temporal area) is associated with epidural hematomas, which present as a lens-shaped lesion.  
❌ Hyperdense collection around the Circle of Willis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm or arteriovenous malformations. Patients often complain of the “worst headache of my life.” On head CT, SAH appears as hyperdense material filling the subarachnoid space.  
❌ Hyperdense collection within the basal ganglia:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with intraparenchymal hemorrhage secondary to  Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms and subsequent rupture of the lenticulostriate penetrating arteries, often seen in patients with chronic hypertension.  
❌ Multiple hyperdense collections at the gray-white junction  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a diffuse axonal injury (DAI) from a rapid acceleration/deceleration injury. Non-contrast CT will recognize only hemorrhagic lesions at the early stages. MRI (diffusion tensor imaging) is more sensitive for detecting DAI.

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on a 57-year-old man who was found unresponsive on the kitchen floor by his daughter. His medical history is remarkable for a 30 pack year smoking history. The pathologist notes small, red punctate lesions at the upper level of the pons. These findings are associated with which of the following cerebral pathologies?
questions.solution:
This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation involving the rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries). The patient likely suffered a fall with subsequent head trauma, and the traumatic brain injury was ultimately fatal.

Central transtentorial herniation refers to downward displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Other features may range from altered mentation to coma. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries) known as a Duret hemorrhages (a complication which is often fatal). On autopsy, these hemorrhages are described as red punctate lesions at the upper level of the pons.



Option Analysis

❌ Cerebral hypoperfusion:
Incorrect: Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is observed in conditions such as cardiac arrest, hypovolemic shock, poisoning, or head trauma. This condition typically affects cerebral watershed areas found between cerebral vascular territories. These territories include the junction between the anterior and middle cerebral arteries, as well as between the posterior and middle cerebral arteries. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.
❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs secondary to rapid correction of hyponatremia. Manifestations include acute paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, loss of consciousness, or death. The red lesions seen in this patient's autopsy instead imply hemorrhage. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.  
✅ Transtentorial herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the lenticulostriate arteries supplying the basal ganglia (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms) results in intraparenchymal hemorrhage. This condition is most commonly associated with chronic hypertension. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.  
❌ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Incorrect: The clinical manifestation of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is highly variable and includes constitutional symptoms such as headache, malaise, nausea, and dizziness. Long term sequelae includes myocardial injury and delayed neuropsychiatric syndrome. Acute intoxication manifests with  hemorrhagic infarction of the globus pallidus and, less so, the deep white matter. This patient’s autopsy reveals Duret hemorrhages, a complication of central transtentorial herniation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle injury. The patient was the restrained passenger in a stationary vehicle as he was rear-ended by another vehicle traveling approximately 80 miles per hour. The patient’s neck was hyperflexed during the collision and now feels stiff. He is unable to move his arms or legs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 9/min, blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Neurological exam is notable for bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation as well as bilateral loss of motor function below C6. Sensation to soft touch and vibration is unaffected. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained a hyperflexion injury to his neck after a high speed motor vehicle accident. His neurologic exam is notable for bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the C6 level. Together, these findings are concerning for anterior spinal artery occlusion.  

Anterior spinal artery occlusion has numerous causes including emboli, mass effect from tumors, hematoma, traumatic dissection injury, and aortic aneurysm repair. The anterior spinal artery does not have substantial collateral flow and is thus very susceptible to ischemia, especially below the T8 level.      

Damage to the artery results in ischemia to the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, which houses the descending corticospinal tract, ascending spinothalamic tract, as well as autonomic fibers. Clinically, this ischemia manifests with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion. In contrast, the dorsal columns are unaffected and hence, proprioception and vibration sense are preserved. Other associated symptoms include anal sphincter dysfunction, urinary retention, and blood pressure lability due to autonomic dysfunction.    


Option Analysis

✅  Anterior cord syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Central cord syndrome:
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome more commonly occurs due to a forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities. In contrast, both the upper and lower extremities are equally affected in this patient. 
❌ Brown-Sequard syndrome:
Incorrect: Brown-Sequard syndrome refers to hemisection of the spinal cord that usually occurs due to a penetrating injury to the spine. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration sense, and proprioception, as well as contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. 
❌  Cauda equina syndrome :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from the compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia. The condition would not manifest with complete paralysis and loss of temperature and pain sensation below the C6 level. 
❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when brain tissue herniates under the falx cerebri, resulting in compression of the anterior cerebral artery. This compression leads to infarction of the medial frontal and parietal lobes, which can manifest with contralateral lower extremity weakness.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a fall at a construction site. His colleague who witnessed the event reports that the patient hit his head and lost consciousness. On arrival, the patient is responsive to pain only. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. On physical examination, the skull is intact, and diffuse bruising is noted. Neck stiffness is present. Motor examination reveals flaccid paralysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of hypotension, bradycardia, neck stiffness, and flaccid paralysis suggests tonsillar herniation secondary to intracranial bleeding (e.g. subdural hematoma).

Tonsillar herniation (also called downward cerebellar herniation) is a type of infratentorial herniation in which there is a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum–resulting in compression of the lower brain stem and upper cervical spinal cord. Clinical manifestations include neck stiffness, flaccid paralysis, decreased level of consciousness, disconjugate eye movements, and nystagmus. Abrupt respiratory depression and blood pressure instability occur secondary to the compression of respiratory and cardiac control centers in the brain stem. The flaccid paralysis is the result of a decreased level of consciousness.



Option Analysis

❌ Hypovolemic shock:
Incorrect: While internal bleeding can lead to hypotension, the heart rate is expected to be increased in a compensatory effort. In addition, hypovolemic shock would not explain the patient’s respiratory depression or neck stiffness.  
❌ Central transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Central transtentorial herniation refers to the downward displacement of the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. This type of herniation may result in small, fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement ("sunset eyes") and diabetes insipidus due to compression of the pituitary stalk. Central herniation may also result in rupture of branches of the basilar artery (pontine arteries) known as Duret hemorrhages. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a different type of brain herniation.  
❌ Subfalcine herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (subfalcine) herniation refers to the lateral displacement of the innermost part of the frontal lobe (the cingulate gyrus) under the falx cerebri. This displacement can cause compression of the anterior cerebral artery and infarction of the frontal and parietal lobes. Clinical features of cingulate herniation are not well defined but may include unilateral/bilateral weakness, loss of bladder control, and coma. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a different type of brain herniation.  
✅ Tonsillar herniation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse axonal injury  :
Incorrect: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) refers to the shearing of white matter tracts, seen commonly in motor vehicle crashes with an acceleration-deceleration mechanism. Patients are often comatose without elevated intracranial pressure at presentation. On neuroimaging, DAI is characterized by multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction. While diffuse axonal injury may occur due to falls, it would not explain the respiratory depression, hypotension, and neck stiffness in this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a sudden onset, severe headache. The headache began abruptly one hour ago with associated emesis. Her medical history is remarkable for migraines, for which she takes sumatriptan as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 170/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and in pain. Nuchal rigidity is present on physical exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy woman presents with a sudden onset, severe generalized headache, with associated hypertension and neck stiffness; this presentation is consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

SAH refers to the pooling of blood in the subarachnoid space. Major causes include rupture of a pre-existing saccular “berry” aneurysm (most common) or, less commonly, bleeding from an arteriovenous malformation, tumor or traumatic injury. Patients often present with the “worst headache of my life” (thunderclap headache) or a headache that reaches maximum intensity within seconds to minutes.

Common findings include a brief loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain/stiffness, and focal neurologic deficits. Diagnosis is performed with a non-contrast CT-brain that will reveal blood in the subarachnoid space. If inconclusive, a lumbar puncture is indicated, which may show bloody or yellow cerebrospinal fluid called xanthochromia (as a result of the broken down blood products in the CSF). Treatment of SAH involves surgical clipping or coiling of the ruptured aneurysm.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Subdural hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Rupture of the bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas, which may be acute due to high energy trauma (e.g. motor vehicle accident) or chronic from low energy trauma (e.g. as seen in cases of brain atrophy, secondary to older age or chronic alcohol use). The CT in a subdural hematoma shows a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines. This patient's presentation occurs outside the setting of trauma.  
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis typically presents with the classic triad of fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status. Patients often complain of photophobia. The majority of patients have high fevers, typically greater than 38°C (100.4°F). This patient’s presentation is more concerning for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which also commonly presents with nuchal rigidity.  
❌ Migraine:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are characterized by unilateral, throbbing/pulsatile pain that usually lasts 4 to 72 hours. It is often associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, or noise sensitivity. While this patient has a history of migraine headaches, the presence of neck stiffness, generalized headache and hypertension suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage.  
✅ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intracerebral hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Intracerebral hemorrhage may present with headache, vomiting, and altered mentation that develops when the hemorrhage becomes large. However, intracerebral hemorrhage typically develops more gradually than subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a fall during a climbing trip. Her partner, who accompanied her, reports that the patient fell from a 4-meter height and hit her head. En route to the hospital, the patient is comatose and unresponsive. Glasgow Coma Score is 3. She is sedated and intubated. On arrival, her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 43/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/70 mmHg. On physical examination, her arms are stiff and bent, with clenched fists and outstretched legs. Both pupils are fixed and dilated. A non-contrast CT is obtained and shows a large biconvex-shaped lesion. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction.

questions.solution:
This patient with an epidural hematoma presents in a coma with fixed and dilated pupils, decorticate posturing, and the Cushing triad of hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration. She has suffered a severe traumatic brain injury and now exhibits signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and impending cerebral herniation. A characteristic finding of elevated ICP is papilledema (i.e. swelling of the optic disk).

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a cardinal cause of disability and mortality. The severity of TBI is commonly graded by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). Severe TBI is defined by a GCS score <9, moderate as 9-12, and mild as 13-15.

Prehospital management is aimed to prevent and treat hypotension and hypoxia because the brain is vulnerable to secondary insults, especially in the first 24 hours. This treatment is usually done via intubation and fluid resuscitation. In patients like this case who present to the emergency department with signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and impending cerebral herniation, such as unilateral or bilateral fixed and dilated pupils, decorticate or decerebrate posturing, and the "Cushing triad" (hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration), prompt endotracheal intubation, head elevation, and hyperventilation should commence immediately. Hyperventilation reduces the PCO2 levels, causing vasoconstriction of the cerebral vessels and thus decreasing the brain blood flow and ICP. Intravascular injection of hyperosmolar agents such as hypertonic saline or mannitol can also be considered.



Option Analysis

✅ Swelling of the optic disk:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Xanthochromia in cerebrospinal fluid  :
Incorrect: Xanthochromia is found in the setting of subarachnoid, not epidural, hemorrhage. The presence of a large biconvex-shaped lesion on CT suggests the later diagnosis.  
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of bridging veins is most commonly associated with subdural hematomas. CT findings of subdural hematomas show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.  
❌ Multiple small lesions within the gray-white junction.  :
Incorrect:  While diffuse axonal injury (DAI) may occur due to falls, patients with DAI specifically present in a coma without evidence of elevated intracranial pressure. This patient has evidence of cerebral edema.  
❌ Unilateral facial paralysis:
Incorrect: Unilateral facial paralysis, or any focal neurologic deficit, is more likely to be found in ischemic or embolic stroke. This patient presents with evidence of cerebral edema and impending herniation, which is characterized by a global decreased level of consciousness and coma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following head trauma secondary to a ski accident. The patient slammed headfirst into a tree and was found unresponsive at the scene. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 190/70 mmHg. Glasgow coma scale is 8, and she is subsequently intubated and mechanically ventilated. On physical examination, there is a bruise noted to the left side temporal area. The left eye is abducted with downward displacement. The left pupil is dilated and areflexic to light. A non-contrast CT is obtained and shows a large, lens-shaped lesion with midline shift. Which of the following describes an early complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left-sided epidural hematoma, midline shift, and an ipsilateral down and out dilated pupil, consistent with uncal herniation. One of the established complications of an uncal herniation is occipital lobe infarction due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, resulting in stroke of the occipital lobe and subsequent homonymous hemianopia.

In uncal herniation (transtentorial herniation), the innermost part of the temporal lobe known as the uncus compresses the tentorium. This area houses the 3rd cranial nerve, the cerebral peduncles, and the posterior cerebral arteries, with herniation resulting in oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and occipital lobe infarction, respectively.

The vision is lost in halves that are contralateral to the posterior cerebral artery that is affected. Although there is a partial loss of vision, macular function is spared, meaning that central vision remains sharp and detailed. This phenomenon occurs because the part of the occipital lobe that supplies the macula receives blood from both the posterior cerebral artery as well as the middle cerebral artery.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Vasospasm of the cerebral vessels:
Incorrect: Delayed cerebral ischemia due to vasospasm of the cerebral vessels is a common complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage after the first 48 hours. Vasospasm is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker, should be administered to prevent this complication.  
❌ Multifocal myoclonus  :
Incorrect: Multifocal myoclonus may occur as a result of metabolic coma (hepatic or uremic encephalopathy). Metabolic coma is characterized by symmetric neurologic deficits, tremor, and asterixis.  
❌ Locked-in syndrome:
Incorrect: Locked-in syndrome is a post-stroke syndrome of the basilar artery characterized by preserved consciousness, quadriplegia, and the inability to move the facial muscles. Patients retain the ability of voluntary blinking and vertical eye movement.  
✅ Homonymous hemianopsia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of progressive headaches and vomiting. The patient slipped from the stage during cheerleading practice, two meters (6.6 feet) high. She fell and hit her head on the tile floor. Afterward, she felt confused, vomited twice, and developed a severe headache. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient becomes somnolent, does not respond when her name is called, but responds to painful stimuli. A non-contrast head CT reveals an epidural hematoma. The patient is admitted for emergent craniotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided during this patient’s surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive headaches and vomiting after a fall. Imaging reveals an epidural hematoma. These findings are concerning for elevated intracranial pressure.

Ketamine acts by blocking NMDA receptors. It has a rapid onset but a longer duration of action than other intravenous anesthetics. Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure (ICP). Therefore, patients with elevated ICP (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage, tumor) should avoid the medication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that potentiates the effects of GABAA on its receptors. It can be administered to patients with traumatic brain injury and elevated intracranial pressures. Cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP) are reduced with induction doses of propofol.  
✅ Ketamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that can cause anterograde amnesia, hypotension, and respiratory depression. The medication decreases intracranial pressure and is not contraindicated in individuals with intracranial hemorrhage.  
❌ Methohexital:
Incorrect: Methohexital is a barbiturate that causes a dose-dependent reduction in cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP). In addition, methohexital does not affect cerebral autoregulation of blood flow in response to carbon dioxide levels. As a result, the medication can be safely given to patients with elevated intracranial pressure.  
❌ Etomidate:
Incorrect: Etomidate is an induction agent that decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP). As a result, the medication can be safely administered to individuals with elevated intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle collision. The paramedics' team found the patient unconscious in the street. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. He does not respond to verbal stimuli but withdraws all extremities to pain. Medical records reveal a past medical history of congestive heart failure. A CT scan of the head shows diffuse cerebral edema. The patient is started on mannitol to decrease the intracranial pressure. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s elevated intracranial pressure is being treated with mannitol. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that rapidly increases the plasma or tubular fluid osmolality, causing water to move from the intracellular space into the vascular or tubular lumen. This effect can worsen or precipitate edematous states like pulmonary edema. Moreover, when more water gets pulled into the blood vessels, the concentration of sodium will go down, resulting in hyponatremia. This side effect is likely to happen in individuals with renal impairment. The kidneys cannot excrete the mannitol, or congestive heart failure, where the heart cannot handle the increased plasma volume.    

Therefore, mannitol is generally contraindicated in congestive heart failure or anuria.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pulmonary edema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proximal renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Proximal renal tubular acidosis is a known side effect of acetazolamide. It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that causes self-limited sodium bicarbonate diuresis and decreases total body bicarbonate stores. In contrast, this side effect does not take place with mannitol therapy.  
❌ Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are ototoxic and can cause sensorineural hearing loss. In contrast, this side effect is not associated with mannitol therapy.  
❌ Arrhythmia:
Incorrect: Arrhythmia is a critical side effect of potassium-sparing diuretics such as spironolactone, secondary to hyperkalemia. Mannitol is not associated with arrhythmias.  
❌ Angioedema:
Incorrect: Angioedema is a side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors resulting from bradykinin accumulation. In contrast, this side effect is not associated with mannitol therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty walking and recurrent falls. The patient states, “I’m not sure what’s wrong with me. I just can’t seem to keep my balance. I just feel like I’m in a fog all day.” The patient also has numbness and tingling in the tips of her fingers and toes. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. The patient currently takes levothyroxine, amlodipine, and metformin. She works as a school teacher and drinks 3-4 glasses of wine per day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an ataxic gait and 3+ reflexes in the upper and lower extremities. The patient has diminished two-point discrimination in the upper extremities with preservation of pinprick sensation. This patient's clinical presentation reflects damage to which of the following anatomic sites?

choices.text: Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns
Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple risk factors for developing vitamin B12 deficiency (cobalamin), including chronic alcohol use and metformin use. Additionally, the physical examination demonstrates dysfunction of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, consistent with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.    

Several spinal cord pathologies can be identified via a careful neurological examination to reveal the affected spinal cord tract(s). For example, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord results when vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absent or deficient. It may become deficient due to malabsorptive disease (e.g., Crohn disease, pernicious anemia), dietary restriction (e.g. veganism), or medications that interfere with cobalamin absorption (e.g., metformin, proton pump inhibitors). When physiologic stores of vitamin B12 are low, levels of methylmalonic acid increase, which causes degeneration of the myelin sheath of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, resulting in subacute combined degeneration (SCD). SCD manifests with symptoms of gait ataxia, paresthesias, and impaired position/vibration sense. Furthermore, SCD can cause psychiatric symptoms, including worsening depression or signs of dementia.    

Additional noteworthy patterns of spinal cord pathologies include Brown-Sequard syndrome, syringomyelia, and tabes dorsalis. Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that occurs following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract damage. In addition, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure). Brown-Sequard syndrome may also be associated with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) if the lesion occurs above the T1 level and causes damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.    

Syringomyelia describes a cystic cavity within the spinal cord, usually within the central canal, that can expand over time and compress the anterior white commissure, a structure directly anterior to the cervical canal. The anterior white commissure is the decussation site for the spinothalamic tracts, relaying pain and temperature sensation. As a result, syringomyelia causes a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. Syringomyelia is associated with Chiari I malformation, a congenital condition characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that herniate below the level of the foramen magnum.  

Lastly, tabes dorsalis arises due to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by Treponema pallidum, the spirochete that causes syphilis. Tertiary infection of the spinal cord leads to demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal column and roots, resulting in findings of gait ataxia and incoordination. The condition takes nearly 20 years to develop after the initial infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior white commissure  :
Incorrect: Chiari I malformation is characterized by cerebellar tonsillar ectopia and is most commonly associated with a syrinx within the spinal cord. Most cases are asymptomatic. In symptomatic patients, the condition can result in a bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities due to impingement on the anterior white commissure.  
❌ Dorsal columns and roots  :
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary neurosyphilis and is characterized by degenerative changes of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Tabes dorsalis would not typically present with signs of spastic paralysis. 
❌ Lumbar spinal roots  :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to a mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.  
❌ Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure :
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome commonly occurs due to forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated at the office for gait disturbance. A social worker referred the patient due to frequent falls. Past medical history includes alcoholic fatty liver disease. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks approximately 60 oz of alcohol every week. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is cooperative and oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination demonstrates mild gaze-evoked horizontal nystagmus. The patient has a wide-based gait. Tapping the patellar tendons elicits persistent, slow, back and forth swinging of the legs.  Finger-to-nose testing shows no abnormalities. Romberg sign is absent. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Sensation is intact in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows no abnormalities. Which of the following additional features is likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with gait and truncal ataxia in the absence of cognitive impairment and a history of heavy alcohol use, suggestive of alcoholic cerebellar degeneration. This condition is typically seen in patients with a history of heavy, long-term (> 10 years) alcohol use and is caused by the degeneration of Purkinje cells of the cerebellar vermis.

The cerebellum is divided into two symmetric hemispheres connected via the vermis. The phylogenetically old archicerebellum consists of the flocculus, the nodulus (nodule of the vermis), and interconnections (flocculonodular system). Together, these structures coordinate equilibrium via connections with the vestibular system. The paleocerebellum consists of the anterior portions of the hemispheres and the anterior and posterior vermis to coordinate propulsive, stereotyped movements, such as walking. The remainder of the cerebellum, termed the neocerebellum, coordinates fine motor movements.

Patients with midline cerebellar lesions exhibit symptoms such as gait ataxia (especially on tandem gait), truncal ataxia, and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Postural incoordination (e.g., inability to tandem walk and abnormal heel-to-shin test) and a pendular knee reflex due to hypotonia is also seen in some patients. Patients may develop a postural tremor of fingers and thighs, dysarthria, and visual disturbance at later stages.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hearing loss  :
Incorrect: Disorders affecting the inner ear and vestibulocochlear nerve can present with hearing loss and gait instability. Common causes include trauma, infection, and Meniere disease. Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration, which is not associated with hearing loss, is a more likely etiology in this case.  
✅ Postural tremor  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Homonymous hemianopia  :
Incorrect: A unilateral visual pathway lesion beyond the optic chiasm can cause homonymous hemianopia. This is often observed with intracerebral hemorrhage affecting the basal ganglia and the occipital lobe.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect  :
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect is observed with lesions of the brain's nondominant temporoparietal or posterior parietal areas.  
❌ Bradykinesia  :
Incorrect: Bradykinesia is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD). Other features of PD include resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Deep-tendon reflexes are typically normal.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son due to an “inability to take care of himself.” The patient is unable to prepare food, bathe himself, or take daily medications. According to the son, his father has had difficulty remembering recent events, such as his grandson’s birthday party last month, but he is able to recall events that occurred many years ago, such as his own wedding. Eight months ago, the patient was forced to give up driving after he got lost in his own neighborhood on numerous occasions. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present within the neurons of this patient’s brain?

choices.text: Intracellular aggregates of improperly cleaved precursor protein
Round eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions due to viral infection
Brownish-yellow granular material composed of lipid and protein

questions.solution:
Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common cause of irreversible dementia in elderly patients. AD typically manifests with an insidious onset of impaired higher intellectual function, impaired memory, as well as alterations in mood and behavior.

The fundamental abnormality in AD is the accumulation of amyloid-beta (Aβ) plaques and tau protein tangles in specific regions of the brain. These events result in neuronal inflammation, dysfunction, and death.

Aβ plaques are created when the transmembrane protein amyloid precursor protein (APP) is improperly cleaved, resulting in insoluble fibrils that eventually aggregate and form extracellular amyloid plaques. As a result, patients who have abnormal APP processing (e.g. presenilin mutations), impaired Aβ clearance (e.g. ApoE4 allele), or elevated production of APP (e.g. trisomy 21), are at increased risk of developing AD.

Tau, on the other hand, is a microtubule-associated protein present in neuronal axons. In patients with AD, these proteins become hyperphosphorylated and give rise to intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (indicated by the black arrow). The hyperphosphorylated tau is no longer able to stabilize microtubules, leading to cytoskeleton damage and neuronal injury.



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperphosphorylated microtubule-associated proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intracellular aggregates of improperly cleaved precursor protein:
Incorrect: The transmembrane protein amyloid precursor protein (APP) is normally neuroprotective. However, in patients with Alzheimer disease, there is improper enzymatic cleavage of this protein. The abnormal proteins eventually aggregate and form extracellular, not intracellular, plaques.
❌ Alpha-synuclein-positive cytoplasmic inclusions:
Incorrect: Neurons contain a protein called alpha-synuclein, and in Lewy body dementia, this protein is misfolded within the neurons. The misfolded alpha-synuclein then aggregates to form Lewy bodies that deposit inside neurons and appear as eosinophilic inclusions under microscopy.
❌ Round eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions due to viral infection:
Incorrect: Negri bodies are cytoplasmic inclusion bodies that occur due to rabies virus accumulation within the neurons. Patients typically present with hydrophobia, central nervous system symptoms (e.g., confusion, hallucinations, agitation), and eventually coma and death.
❌ Brownish-yellow granular material composed of lipid and protein:
Incorrect: Lipofuscin, commonly known as the “wear-and-tear pigment,” is an insoluble intracellular material that accumulates in a variety of tissues (e.g., heart, liver, brain) with aging. It is not injurious to the cell but is indicative of past free radical injury.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to odd behavior for the past several months. He was born at 38 weeks by vaginal delivery to a 29-year primigravida mother. The patient’s development has been normal, and all milestones have been reached. He performs well at school and language development is normal. The parents report that a couple of months ago, the patient started blinking excessively, which she attributed to dry eyes and allergies. Recently, the patient started grimacing often and occasionally moans for no apparent reason. The parents are worried because the patient has been bullied in school for the behavior. Vitals and physical examination are within normal limits. This patient is at increased risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient has vocal tics (moaning) and motor tics (blinking, grimacing), a presentation that raises concern for Tourette syndrome (TS). The diagnosis of TS can be made if symptoms persist > 1 year.  

TS is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and phonic tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to a disturbance in the cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical (mesolimbic) circuit which results in disinhibition of the limbic and motor systems. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition and are typically sudden, brief, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

The majority of patients with TS have at least one or more comorbid problem. Most associations include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Other comorbid conditions are learning disabilities, conduct disorder/oppositional defiant disorder, anxiety disorders, sleep disorders, mood disorders and increased risk of suicide.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.



Option Analysis

✅ Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epilepsy:
Incorrect: Epilepsy has not been shown to be associated with Tourette syndrome.
❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although children with Tourette syndrome are at increased risk for conduct disorder, there is minimal evidence showing predisposition for developing antisocial personality disorder. 
❌ Type 1 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Patients with Tourette syndrome (TS) are at increased risk of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disorders. An added risk factor is that many children with TS are managed with antipsychotics (such as olanzapine), which carry the risk of adverse metabolic effects, such as weight gain, diabetes and hyperlipidemia. However, there is minimal evidence suggesting an increased risk of type 1 diabetes.
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: This patient has vocal tics (moaning) and motor tics (blinking, grimacing), a presentation that raises concern for Tourette syndrome (TS). The diagnosis of TS can be made if symptoms persist > 1 year.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive abnormal movement of the hands for the past several years. The patient first noticed both of his hands started shaking 3 years ago, and since then, the shaking has gotten worse. It occurs mainly when he reaches for objects, such as a glass of water or a magazine. The patient mentions that he had “shaky hands” in college when he studied for his finals and drank multiple cups of coffee. Medical history is non-contributory. The patient’s mother died from Alzheimer disease complications at the age of 79, and his father died of myocardial infarction at age 55. He recalls his father had a similar condition but cannot recall any details. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress and no shaking is present at rest. When the patient is asked to outstretch his arms, a mild oscillating, flexion-extension movement is noted bilaterally. Neurological examination, including gait, is within normal limits, except a positive finger-to-nose test, which shows mild tremor after reaching the target. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with a progressive, bilateral intention tremor along with a normal neurological examination, most likely has essential tremor (ET). In contrast, the tremor that occurred during college was most likely physiologic tremor, exacerbated by sleep deprivation and excessive caffeine intake.  

Tremor is defined as a rhythmic, involuntary, oscillatory movement of a body part caused by either alternating or synchronous antagonist muscle contractions. ET is the most common cause of action tremor in adults. Classically, ET involves the hands and becomes apparent by arm movement during an activity (intention tremor) or sustained antigravity postures. The tremor can be quite disabling, affecting daily activities such as writing, drinking from a glass, and using utensils. The tremor is typically slowly progressive, bilateral, slightly asymmetric, and with moderate to high frequency (6 to 12 Hz). ET may also affect the head, voice, and less commonly the face or trunk. A helpful clue often seen on USMLE exams is that ET is often relieved by small amounts of alcohol intake, and therefore, patients often self-medicate with alcoholic beverages. The neuropathologic basis of ET remains poorly understood, but involvement of the cerebellum and brainstem (locus coeruleus) has been suggested. ET has a strong genetic component, often referred to as "familial tremor." The diagnosis of ET is based purely upon the clinical features, according to the following criteria:  

  •  Isolated, bilateral upper limb action tremor, without other motor abnormalities 
  •  At least three years in duration 
  •  With/without a tremor in other locations (e.g., head, voice, or lower limbs) 
  •  Absence of other neurologic signs (e.g., parkinsonism, ataxia) 
First-line treatment consists of beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) or certain barbiturates (e.g. primidone).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Essential tremor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Physiologic tremor:
Incorrect: Physiologic tremor is a very low-amplitude, high-frequency (8 to 12 Hz) action tremor that can be seen in healthy individuals. Physiologic tremor is typically not visible under ordinary conditions and may become apparent with increased sympathetic activity (e.g., stress, anxiety, hyperthyroidism, hypoglycemia, alcohol or opioid withdrawal) and certain drugs (e.g. excessive caffeine intake). Physiologic tremor, however, is not progressive or disabling, as seen in this patient. 
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease-associated tremor is typically a resting tremor characterized by "pill-rolling" flexion-supination movement, with a frequency of 4 to 6 Hz. The tremor usually disappears with movement, in contrast to this patient’s tremor that worsens with activity. This patient’s tremor characteristics and normal neurological examination favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Cerebellar lesion:
Incorrect: Cerebellar tremors can occur with conditions that damage the cerebellum. The tremor frequency is typically low (3 to 4 Hz) and intention-type (worse when reaching the target). Although this patient had a positive finger-to-nose test and signs of an intention tremor, the absence of other cerebellar signs such as ataxia and nystagmus favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Dystonia:
Incorrect: Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary, sustained or intermittent muscle contractions that result in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. It may be focal or generalized. Writer's dystonia, also known as writer's cramp, is an example of a task-specific hand dystonia elicited by writing. Overlying dystonic spasms are often confused with essential tremor. However, in contrast to essential tremor, dystonia tremor is often unilateral and triggered by task-specific activities, such as writing or typing.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the clinic with his partner due to episodes of uncontrollable crying and laughing, as well as abnormal body movements. The partner states that the patient has not been himself for the past year. In the beginning, she thought that he was going through a tough time because he was fired from his job as an accountant. He was constantly making mistakes, and his boss eventually released him after multiple poor performance reviews. The patient’s partner started worrying when she noticed him making odd movements with his hands. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears restless and sad. There is a mild hand tremor present on the right and occasional brief, abrupt movement of the right upper extremity as well as occasional facial grimacing. The patient walks in slow small steps. Which of the following is most likely to be found on brain imaging of this patient?

choices.text: Cortical atrophy of the parietal and temporal lobe region
Apparent ventricle enlargement with diffuse brain atrophy

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disease that follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.  

The underlying pathophysiology is an increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4. Mutant huntingtin contains an expanded tract of glutamine residues that results in an abnormal protein toxic to neurons. The condition is characterized by anticipation, which refers to increased severity and earlier onset in succeeding generations due to expansion of CAG repeats. On imaging, atrophy of the caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly can be seen. The latter refers to the apparent enlargement of the ventricles when the brain is atrophied. Symptoms manifest between the ages of 20 and 50 and include chorea, athetosis, aggression, depression, and dementia. There is no cure for Huntington disease, and treatment is aimed to control the symptoms.    

Option Analysis

❌ Periventricular and juxtacortical plaques:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune  neurodegenerative disease characterized by immune-mediated inflammatory demyelination of the central nervous system. Common presenting symptoms include pyramidal signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity), cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), and spinal cord symptoms (e.g., neurogenic bladder, paraparesis).
❌ Cortical atrophy of the parietal and temporal lobe region:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Alzheimer disease, the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Alzheimer disease typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings.
❌ Temporal and frontal lobe degeneration:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with frontotemporal dementia, which is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior, aphasia, and occasionally parkinsonism. 
✅ Apparent ventricle enlargement with diffuse brain atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with vascular dementia, a condition caused by multiple infarcts and/or chronic ischemia. Common presenting symptoms include a stepwise decline in cognitive ability and late-onset memory impairment.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the office by his partner for evaluation of impaired memory. About three-months ago, the patient started frequently misplacing objects and having difficulty performing his responsibilities as an accountant. His symptoms worsened two weeks ago, when he developed difficulty walking and frequently tripped over himself. The patient still enjoys playing poker with his friends weekly, but he has found it increasingly difficult to remain competitive. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes daily medications. His last HbA1c from one month ago was 9.6%. He drinks 3-4 glasses of wine per week, and he does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. In the office, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/94 mmHg. Physical exam reveals no abnormalities. Head CT shows multiple hypodense lesions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has experienced a stepwise decline in neurocognitive function, which is concerning for vascular dementia (VD). Patients with VD typically have multiple cardiovascular risk factors, such as chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking. There are generally two forms of vascular dementia:  

  •  Small vessel disease is caused by lipohyalinosis, amyloid beta deposition, and/or microatheroma of cerebral vessels. These changes lead to lacunar infarcts and cortical microinfarcts. Due to the chronic nature of this disease, there is a gradual or stepwise worsening of dementia. Early symptoms include impaired memory and reduced executive functioning. In the later stages, patients can develop disorientation, mood disorders, and behavioral changes. 
 
  •  Large vessel disease is caused primarily by atherosclerosis that leads to cerebral cortex ischemia. In patients with multi-infarct dementia, there is a similar stepwise progression of symptoms. However, in patients with single-infarct dementia, there is a single major ischemic event such as a stroke, upon which there would be sudden-onset dementia.

Head imaging (e.g., CT, MRI) would show multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts that are indicative of repeated ischemic events.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral arteriosclerosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thiamine deficiency :
Incorrect: Thiamine deficiency can result in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and is classically seen in patients with chronic alcohol use. Patients present with nystagmus, ataxia, confusion, and confabulations to fill lapses in memory. Thiamine deficiency is unlikely in this patient, who consumes only a moderate amount of alcohol and lacks physical exam findings suggestive of chronic alcohol use disorder (e.g., jaundice, ascites). 
❌ Impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption. Patients classically present with the triad of urinary incontinence, ataxic gait, and cognitive impairments. However, the stepwise decline in this patient’s neurocognitive function is more concerning for vascular dementia.
❌ Lewy body deposition:
Incorrect: Lewy body deposition occurs in Parkinson disease and Lewy body dementia. Patients with Parkinson disease typically present with tremors, rigidity, akinesia, and bradykinesia, whereas Lewy body dementia classically presents with visual hallucinations and Parkinsonian symptoms. This patient does not have tremors or hallucinations, making Lewy body deposition less unlikely. 
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: In elderly patients, depression can manifest with symptoms similar to dementia (also termed “pseudodementia”). This patient, however, continues to have interest in his hobbies. Furthermore, major depressive disorder would not account for the abnormal lesions seen on the head CT.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her mother for worsening “odd dancing movements.” Symptoms have been present for the past year. The patient recently moved back home after she was fired from her job due to a “lack of interest.” Additionally, the patient has found it increasingly difficult to perform daily tasks, such as housekeeping and cooking. The patient’s father had similar symptoms and eventually passed away from complications of pneumonia. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 138/77 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination reveals involuntary, irregular movements of the patient’s head and face. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Mutant protein with expanded glutamine tract
Gene hypermethylation with impaired protein production
Mutant RNA formation with impaired translation
Point mutation resulting in loss of glutamic acid residue

questions.solution:
Huntington disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder that arises due to mutations in the HTT gene. The gene encodes huntingtin, a ubiquitously expressed protein. Huntingtin contains a polyglutamine tract encoded by uninterrupted CAG trinucleotide repeats; normally, it can contain up to 35 CAG repeats, whereas patients with HD carry expansions of 36 or more repeats. There is a strong inverse correlation between the number of CAG repeats and age of symptom onset. In other words, the greater the number of CAG repeats, the earlier the age of onset.
