As a result, HD is characterized by the genetic phenomenon of anticipation, wherein there increased severity and earlier disease onset in succeeding generations due to trinucleotide repeat expansion.

Clinically, Huntington disease typically manifests in individuals between the ages of 20-50. In the early stages, it can present with involuntary movements such as chorea (dance-like movements) and athetosis (involuntary writhing movements). In the later stages, cognitive decline and behavioral changes may manifest in the form of dementia, aggression, apathy, and depression.  



Option Analysis

✅ Mutant protein with expanded glutamine tract :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitochondrial iron overload :
Incorrect: Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat disorder that arises due to a mutation in frataxin, a protein involved in iron-binding. The mutation results in impaired mitochondrial iron management with subsequent iron overload. The resulting oxidative stress causes death of cells that are dependent on aerobic respiration (e.g., heart, neurons, skeletal muscle). Patients typically present with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and cerebellar and spinal cord degeneration in childhood. 
❌ Gene hypermethylation with impaired protein production:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder resulting from hypermethylation of the FMR1 gene; methylation is a mechanism used by cells to repress gene expression. The protein product of this gene is heavily involved in prenatal and postnatal brain development. Patients with fragile X syndrome typically present with intellectual disability and a characteristic elongated face with a large jaw. 
❌ Mutant RNA formation with impaired translation :
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder that results in the production of mutant, toxic RNAs. These toxic RNAs alter RNA-binding protein activity, resulting in abnormal splicing and translation of several genes involved in skeletal and cardiac muscle function. Patients typically present in early adulthood with progressive muscle wasting and weakness, as well as arrhythmias.
❌ Point mutation resulting in loss of glutamic acid residue:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the β-hemoglobin chain, which results in a single amino acid substitution of glutamic acid with valine. Patients with this condition typically present early in childhood with anemia and episodes of painful vaso-occlusive crises.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office escorted by his partner due to recent falls and confusion. Additionally, the partner states that multiple times throughout the night, the patient exhibits various movements in his sleep, such as throwing a ball and even accidentally kicking her one night. The patient states he is unaware of these activities, but he describes vivid dreams of playing football or fighting off home invaders. The patient’s partner mentions that the symptoms began a year ago, and since then, they have been getting worse, although some days are better than others. Medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals muscle rigidity in the upper extremities, and the patient walks slowly with small steps. On Mini-Mental State Examination the patient has difficulty with copying overlapping pentagons and drawing a clock but can repeat 3 objects after 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient, who is presenting with parkinsonism (rigidity, shuffling gait), rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder, as well as fluctuating symptoms (good and bad days), most likely has dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB).  

 DLB is a common type of degenerative dementia. In addition to dementia, a patient with DLB must have at least two of the core features, including: 
  •  cognitive fluctuations 
  •  visual hallucinations 
  •  rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD) 
  •  parkinsonism    
Patients typically show an early decline in executive function (e.g. calculations), and visuoperceptual ability (e.g. missing traffic signs). On the Mini-Mental Exam, although not diagnostic, patients with DLB have impaired figure copying, clock drawing, and serial sevens, compared to Alzheimer disease, which shows impaired short-term memory and orientation. The diagnosis of DLB is based upon the presence of core clinical features, history, and physical examination. MRI will likely show nonspecific diffuse cortical atrophy. The hallmark of the disease is the presence of Lewy bodies on pathological examination of the brain, which are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregated alpha-synuclein in the deep cortical layers.  

The differentiation of Parkinson disease from DLB is based on the timeline of which symptoms occur. If the parkinsonism symptoms are present for more than a year before the onset of dementia, the diagnosis is instead classified as Parkinson disease dementia.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is an idiopathic neurodegenerative disorder which typically presents after 60 years of age; it is the most common cause of dementia. Declarative episodic memory, vocabulary, and concepts are typically impaired while procedural memory and motor learning are spared. This patient shows intact short term memory and parkinsonism, which favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia, formerly known as Pick disease, is characterized by early personality and behavior changes or aphasia. Patients with frontotemporal dementia may also have associated movement disorders (e.g. parkinsonism). However, the REM-sleep disturbances and the order of the progression of this patient’s presentation favor another diagnosis.
❌ Normal-pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is an idiopathic condition characterized by expansion of the ventricles and distortion of the corona radiata fibers. Patients typically present with a classic triad of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (magnetic gait), and cognitive dysfunction. This patient’s clinical symptoms favors another diagnosis. 
✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect:  Vascular dementia is caused as a result of multiple arterial infarcts. It is typically seen in patients with longstanding cardiovascular conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes) and characterized by a stepwise decline in cognitive ability with late-onset memory impairment; it does not cause parkinsonism symptoms as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the office because of increased frequency of falls, loss of balance, and blurry vision for the past several months. His partner mentions that the patient has been moodier, has difficulty coming up with names of places, and “gets aggravated easily if he does not get his way.” Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient moves slowly and walks with small steps. There is rigidity noted in the extremities, and a fine tremor in the bilateral hands. Eye examination shows a limited upward and downward gaze with slowing of vertical saccades bilaterally. The fundal margins are clear without edema. A therapeutic dose of levodopa is administered and does not result in improvement of the patient’s rigidity or tremors. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability with unexplained falls), and cognitive dysfunction, most likely has progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).  

Symptoms and signs of parkinsonism (i.e., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are also present in other neurodegenerative disorders aside from idiopathic Parkinson disease, known as “Parkinson-Plus syndromes.” These include corticobasal degeneration, multiple system atrophy, and progressive supranuclear palsy.  

PSP is characterized by progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, gait disorder, postural instability, dysarthria, dysphagia, rigidity, and frontal cognitive disturbance (personality and behavior changes). Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia is the hallmark of PSP; it typically begins with slowing of vertical saccades, followed by a limitation of saccadic range. Patients often present with downgaze palsy and later, an upgaze palsy.

The cause of the condition is unknown, but it is associated with the accumulation of tau protein within the brain. The pathological correlates associated with this syndrome are atrophy of the dorsal midbrain, subthalamic nucleus, basal ganglia, and frontal lobes. Neurofibrillary tangles, neuronal loss, and gliosis are also seen.  

Parkinson disease (PD) is a common differential diagnosis for PSP; however, PD does not normally present with symmetrical onset. Additionally, PSP patients have a poor response to levodopa therapy, in contrast to idiopathic PD.  



Option Analysis

❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. AD typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings. The timing of this patient’s symptoms and the abnormal eye findings are suggestive of a different, specific diagnosis.
❌ Lewy body dementia:
Incorrect: Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by dementia with fluctuating cognition and alertness, visual hallucinations, and late parkinsonism. This patient's abnormal eye movements are suggestive of a different, specific diagnosis.
❌ Parkinson disease :
Incorrect: Parkinson disease (PD) and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) share bradykinesia, rigidity of muscles, and late-onset dementia. However, abnormal eye movements are rare in PD, while the finding is considered a disease hallmark in PSP patients. 
❌ Multisystem atrophy:
Incorrect: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by autonomic dysfunction, ataxia, and parkinsonism (slow movement, muscle rigidity, tremors, and postural instability). Cognitive function is relatively preserved in MSA compared with Parkinson disease. Although cerebellar disturbances of eye movements can be seen, vertical gaze palsy is not expected in MSA. 
✅ Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with worsening hand and leg weakness. He often feels as if his left leg is “dragging” and experiences “spasms” while running. He additionally has difficulty holding a pen as firmly as he used to. Past medical history is notable for Graves disease. The patient does not smoke, use alcohol or other illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 125/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for 4/5 strength in the right hand, with thenar muscle atrophy, as well as 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity. He has upgoing toes when the inner sole of the left foot is stroked. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease?

choices.text: Combined upper motor and lower motor neuron degeneration
Congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord
Degeneration of the dorsal columns and roots
Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of both upper and lower motor neuron disease including spasticity, a positive Babinski sign, and thenar wasting. These findings raise concern for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).   

ALS is a combined upper and lower motor neuron disease that results in degeneration of the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. The etiology of ALS is unknown, and current research proposes a number of potential mechanisms including abnormal RNA processing, excitotoxicity, cytoskeletal derangements, mitochondrial dysfunction, and growth factor abnormalities. Mutations in the superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD-1) gene are thought to be implicated.    

Regardless, neuronal degeneration in these spinal tracts results in symptoms of both upper (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign) and lower (e.g., fasciculations, atrophy) motor neuron disease. Additional symptoms include dysarthria, dysphagia, and asymmetric limb weakness. Most patients with ALS lack sensory deficits or deficits in bowel or bladder function.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Combined upper motor and lower motor neuron degeneration:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord:
Incorrect: Werdnig-Hoffman disease is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in the SMN1 gene that results in congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord. This disease presents with signs of lower motor neuron disease, and symptoms manifest early in childhood.  
❌   Degeneration of the dorsal columns and roots  :
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary neurosyphilis and is caused by degenerative changes of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. However, tabes dorsalis would not typically present with the signs of muscle weakness seen in this patient. 
❌ Antibodies against postsynaptic ACh receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness. Unlike amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, myasthenia gravis will demonstrate worsening fatigability with repetitive muscle movements and subsequent improvement with rest. Furthermore, myasthenia gravis does not present with features of upper motor neuron disease (e.g., muscle spasm, positive Babinski reflex).  
❌ Disruption of the dystrophin-associated protein complex :
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are associated with mutations in the dystrophin gene, which anchors myofilaments to the extracellular matrix. These disorders can present with muscle weakness. However, symptoms will develop during childhood in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and by early adulthood in Becker muscular dystrophy. It would be unusual for either of these conditions to first manifest with symptoms in a middle-aged individual.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter due to worsening irritability and aggression. Over the past year, the patient has been having trouble recalling the names of her children. She has even gotten lost walking back from the park, which she has done nearly everyday without difficulty for 30 years. According to the daughter, the patient also seems more withdrawn and becomes irritated when asked simple questions. She has not had any hallucinations or changes in urinary frequency or gait. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. She says her mood is “annoyed” and scores 19/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination (normal: ≥ 24). She is oriented to person and place but not time. Which of the following clinical features in this patient’s history is indicative of dementia, as opposed to delirium?
questions.solution:
Major neurocognitive disorder (formerly called dementia) is a condition that affects cognitive functioning and is characterized by impairments in memory, language, executive function, and/or spatial-temporal awareness to the point of restricting a patient’s daily routine. Although normal aging may present with a similar decline in some cognitive areas (e.g. episodic memories), procedural and semantic memories are typically preserved well enough to allow for independence when carrying out daily activities.

There are various causes of dementia, with most cases originating from neurodegenerative conditions (e.g., Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease), which are therefore irreversible. A crucial aspect of dementia is that the cognitive impairment is gradual and progresses over time.

Delirium, on the other hand, may present with similar impairments in cognitive functioning, but the symptoms develop acutely and fluctuate throughout the day. Delirium can occur as a result of a variety of medical conditions and is often a complication of various medications in the elderly. Delirium is a reversible state, and treatment focuses on addressing the underlying condition.



Option Analysis

✅ Progressive course of condition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lack of orientation:
Incorrect: This patient is currently oriented to person and place, but not time. Disorientation can occur in both delirium and dementia.
❌ Mini-Mental State Examination score:
Incorrect: The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a widely used screening tool for delirium and dementia. Patients with dementia will likely have persistently reduced scores, whereas patients with delirium will likely have a transiently reduced score but normal baseline scores. However, a single score would not be enough to distinguish between the two conditions.
❌ Memory deficit:
Incorrect: Both delirium and dementia (e.g. Alzheimer disease) can present with impaired memory. As a result, this clinical feature is specific to neither condition.
❌ Agitation and irritability:
Incorrect: Neuropsychiatric symptoms, such as irritability, agitation, and apathy, are common in Alzheimer disease. These symptoms become more prominent in the middle and later course of the disease. However, patients with delirium (e.g. substance intoxication) can also exhibit these symptoms. As a result, the presence of agitation and irritability is not specific to either delirium or dementia.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining various brain biopsies obtained from patients who died of neurodegenerative conditions. A particular slide she is examining is from the frontal lobe and shown below.  

 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Further testing reveals round cytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregates of tau proteins that stain with silver. Which of the following symptoms did this patient most likely exhibit before his death?

choices.text: Fabricated stories to fill memory lapses
Vivid visual hallucinations of deceased family members

questions.solution:
Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by neuronal cell loss in the frontal and temporal regions of the brain. Microscopic examination will likely reveal neuronal loss, swollen neurons, and astrocytic glial cell proliferation (gliosis). Moreover, two types of abnormal protein inclusions are typically seen in the cytoplasm of neurons:  

  •  Pick bodies are round silver-staining inclusions that consist of hyperphosphorylated tau protein. Pick bodies are seen in many patients with FTD (hence why the condition was previously called Pick syndrome).  
  • TDP-43 protein is an RNA binding protein normally present in the nucleus and involved in the regulation of transcription. Improperly phosphorylated and ubiquitinated TDP-43 can be seen as intracellular inclusions. 
Clinically, FTD is characterized by early behavioral changes (due to frontal lobe degeneration) that can present as disinhibition (e.g., kissing strangers, public urination), apathy, and hyperorality (which can manifest as increased smoking habits). Most patients typically lack insight into their behavioral changes, and they are often brought in for evaluation by concerned and/or embarrassed family members. Another prominent early finding in FTD is progressive aphasia, which can present as deficits in word finding and word comprehension. As the disease progresses, however, patients can begin developing memory loss.  



Option Analysis

✅ Socially inappropriate behavior:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fabricated stories to fill memory lapses:
Incorrect: Korsakoff syndrome is seen in patients with chronic alcohol use and is caused by a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency results in decreased cerebral glucose metabolism and injury to neurons, especially those in the mammillary bodies. Patients with Korsakoff syndrome typically exhibit anterograde and retrograde amnesia and confabulation, wherein they fabricate stories to fill lapses in memory. However, Korsakoff syndrome would not present with the silver-staining Pick bodies seen in the above image.
❌ Vivid visual hallucinations of deceased family members:
Incorrect: Patients with Lewy body dementia can present with vivid hallucinations of animals or people. The condition is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies, which are alpha-synuclein positive cytoplasmic inclusions. These structures appear as hyaline eosinophilic globules found within neurons.
❌ Bradykinesia and tremors:
Incorrect: Lewy bodies are also seen in patients with Parkinson disease, who initially present with bradykinesia and a resting tremor. However, no Lewy bodies are seen in the above image.
❌ Writhing movements and depression:
Incorrect: Huntington disease manifests with choreiform movements, psychiatric illnesses (e.g., depression, psychosis), and dementia. Microscopic examination would reveal severe loss of neurons and gliosis in the striatum, as well as intranuclear inclusions containing aggregates of ubiquitinated huntingtin protein.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to irritability, low mood and abnormal movements of the arms. She has worked as a banker for many years, and over the past several months, she has been receiving poor performance reviews. The patient also describes a jerking movement of the right hand that has been progressively worsening in the past few months. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient mentions her father had some conditions which she cannot recall, and he committed suicide at the age of 61. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious with a low mood. The patient is unable to sit still during the examination and makes repetitive, involuntary movements that are prominent in both the arms and hands. Which of the following will most likely help in establishing the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
The presence of depression, personality changes, cognitive decline, and chorea, in light of this patient’s father's unknown medical condition, raises concern for Huntington disease (HD).  

The diagnosis of HD is based upon the common clinical features, positive family history (such as this patient’s father who committed suicide, likely secondary to neuropsychiatric problems secondary to HD), and genetic confirmation demonstrating the cytosine-adenine-guanine (CAG) trinucleotide expansion of ≥36 repeats in the HTT gene on chromosome 4. Of these, genetic testing is sensitive and specific for HD and allows easy confirmation of atypical patients.  

HD is an autosomal dominant progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by choreiform movements, neuropsychiatric problems, and early dementia. The underlying pathophysiology is an increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4. Mutant huntingtin contains an expanded tract of glutamine residues which results in an abnormal protein toxic to neurons. The condition is characterized by anticipation, which refers to increased severity and earlier onset in succeeding generations due to expansion of CAG repeats. On brain imaging, atrophy of the caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly can be seen. The latter refers to the apparent enlargement of the ventricles when the brain itself is actually atrophied. Symptoms manifest between the ages of 20 and 50 and include chorea, athetosis (slow, involuntary, writhing movements of the extremities), aggression, depression, and dementia. There is no cure for Huntington disease, and treatment is aimed to control the symptoms.  

 

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal (CSF) analysis and detection of 14-3-3 protein is an adjunctive test used for the diagnosis of prion diseases (e.g. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). It has no role in establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease.
❌ Brain biopsy:
Incorrect: Brain biopsy and neuropathologic examination is the gold-standard diagnostic test for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; however, it is rarely used because of the invasiveness, and a probable diagnosis of sporadic CJD can be made with noninvasive testing. Biopsy has no role in establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease.
❌ Family history and physical examination:
Incorrect: Family history and physical examination is important for establishing the diagnosis of Huntington disease; however, it will not confirm the diagnosis -- whereas Parkinson disease, for example, is mainly a clinical diagnosis (i.e. the diagnosis is dependent on the patient’s history and physical examination). 
✅ Genetic testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain can help in the diagnosis of Huntington disease by demonstrating caudate atrophy and by excluding other conditions. However, caudate atrophy occurs late in the course, and it will not confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to sleeping disturbances for the past 2 months. The patient reports an uncomfortable sensation of the legs that occurs especially at night or during prolonged inactivity. She describes the sensation as a “crawling” and “tingling” sensation which makes her wake up multiple times throughout the night. After waking up, walking and moving her legs provides temporary relief. Medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. The patient’s most recent HbA1C was 7.0% one month ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral flat foot, for which she uses orthoses. Monofilament examination of the foot is within normal limits. Achilles reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has restless legs syndrome (RLS), a sleep-related movement disorder characterized by an unpleasant or uncomfortable urge to move the legs that occurs particularly during the evening and times of inactivity which is transiently relieved by movement.  

The pathophysiology of RLS remains incompletely understood, but studies have identified central and peripheral nervous system abnormalities in patients with the disorder. Currently, there is no evidence that neurodegeneration plays a role in RLS. Risk factors include positive family history, sleep deprivation, iron deficiency, uremia secondary to renal failure, spinal cord disease, pregnancy, multiple sclerosis, and Parkinson disease. RLS is a clinical diagnosis and no additional testing is required, with the exception of iron stores evaluation (all patients) and blood urea nitrogen and creatinine if uremia is suspected.  

Mild symptoms may be addressed with behavioral strategies (e.g., exercise, reduced caffeine intake) and avoidance of aggravating factors (e.g. sleep deprivation). However, more severe symptoms that do not respond to nonpharmacologic therapy and correction of iron deficiency require pharmacological intervention such as dopamine agonists (e.g. pramipexole).

 

Option Analysis

❌ Akathisia :
Incorrect: Akathisia refers to an inner sense of restlessness that manifests as an intense desire to move. The restlessness is typically generalized but may be more prominent in the legs; however, complaints of paresthesias and other unpleasant sensations are uncommon.   
❌ Diabetic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathies are caused by microvascular injury involving small blood vessels that supply nerves (vasa nervorum). Patients often present with negative symptoms (e.g., numbness, weakness) and positive symptoms (e.g., tingling, pain). Physical examination typically shows "stocking-glove" sensory loss, decreased or absent ankle reflexes, and as the disease progresses, weakness may develop. This patient has normal monofilament examination, intact reflexes and is at the target value of HbA1C for diabetic patients, all favoring a different diagnosis.   
❌ Tarsal tunnel syndrome:
Incorrect: Tarsal tunnel syndrome (TTS) is a type of neuropathy caused by compression of the tibial nerve as it travels through the tarsal tunnel. Patients often complain of numbness, aching, burning, tingling on the sole of the foot, distal foot, toes, and heel pain. Although there is an association between TTS and flat feet, TTS symptoms are exacerbated by weight-bearing rather than sleeping. Moreover, TTS does not typically cause symptoms above the ankle.  
❌ Nocturnal leg cramps:
Incorrect: Nocturnal leg cramps are a common, multifactorial condition that manifests as paroxysmal spasms involving the muscles of the feet or calf. In contrast to the symptoms of restless leg syndrome, nocturnal leg cramps are sudden, short in duration, and are associated with pain and a palpable muscle contraction.
✅ Restless leg syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to personality changes, difficulty speaking, and impaired balance over the past year. They describe the patient as a previously bright, cheerful child who enjoyed activities at school and socializing with friends. Over the last several months, he has become very impulsive and irritable and is also having significant trouble completing homework on time. The patient also used to be an avid soccer player but recently dropped out of the team due to poor performance and lack of interest. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the patient shows significant loss of coordination and dysarthric speech. Slit-lamp examination of the eyes is shown below:  

 

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
   
Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient on further testing?

choices.text: Basal ganglia atrophy on brain imaging
Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat on genetic testing

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dysarthria, impaired balance, and personality changes, along with a slit-lamp eye examination showing Kayser-Fleischer rings; the most likely diagnosis is Wilson disease.   

Wilson disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from mutations in hepatocyte copper-transporting ATPase (ATP7B gene on chromosome 13). As a result, there is a decrease in copper incorporation into apoceruloplasmin and excretion into bile. Copper accumulates within the liver, brain, cornea, kidneys, and other organs. Kayser-Fleischer rings refer to the deposition of copper (which appears dark brown) within the Descemet membrane in the cornea; the rings are a characteristic feature of Wilson disease.  

There are numerous clinical manifestations associated with Wilson's disease due to copper accumulation in various organs:  

  •  Neurologic manifestations occur largely due to the atrophy of the basal ganglia; these include parkinsonism, dysarthria, tremor, dystonia, and polyneuropathy.  
  •  Psychiatric symptoms can include irritability, psychosis, emotional lability, difficulty concentrating and personality changes.  
  •  Hepatic dysfunction includes hepatitis, hepatomegaly, and eventual liver cirrhosis.         
In patients with clinical features suggestive of Wilson disease, a complete blood count, liver biochemical tests, serum ceruloplasmin and copper levels, and ocular slit-lamp examination, as well as 24-hour urinary copper excretion, help to establish the diagnosis. Treatment includes copper chelation with penicillamine or trientine and oral zinc. A liver transplant is indicated in patients with acute liver failure.




Option Analysis

❌ Insulin resistance:
Incorrect: The insulin resistance of diabetes mellitus is associated with hemochromatosis, a genetic or acquired condition that results in increased iron absorption. Patients often present with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation (“bronze diabetes”). It can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy, hypogonadism, and arthropathy. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen. 
✅ Basal ganglia atrophy on brain imaging:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat on genetic testing:
Incorrect: Increased GAA trinucleotide repeat can be found in patients with Friedreich ataxia, an autosomal recessive condition characterized by degeneration of lateral corticospinal tract, spinocerebellar tract, dorsal columns, and dorsal root ganglia. Patients often present with staggering gait, falling, nystagmus, dysarthria, pes cavus, hammertoes, diabetes mellitus, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and kyphoscoliosis. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen. 
❌ Tumor in the adrenal medulla :
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas are tumors that arise from chromaffin cells of the adrenal gland and secrete catecholamines. These tumors are associated with neurofibromatosis type I and von Hippel-Lindau disease. Patients often present with paroxysmal elevated blood pressure, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Neurofibromatosis type I is associated with Lisch nodules, which are pigmented hamartomatous nodules in the iris, not Kayser-Fleischer rings. 
❌ Hypogonadism:
Incorrect: Hypogonadism is associated with hemochromatosis, a genetic or acquired condition that results in increased iron absorption. Patients often present with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation (“bronze diabetes”). It can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy, hypogonadism, and arthropathy. Kayser-Fleischer rings are not seen.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner for evaluation of worsening confusion and changes in personality. Symptoms began three months ago. The patient has had multiple falls over this same time period, which the partner attributes to his “unsteady gait.” He has not had urinary incontinence, fevers, or hallucinations. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He has never consumed alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient demonstrates nystagmus at rest. He is unable to perform rapidly alternating pronation and supination movements with his hands. The patient scores 17/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination (normal: ≥24). Brain biopsy from a deceased patient with the same condition is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional physical exam findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Sudden involuntary contraction of muscles after a loud sound
Unilateral, violent, flailing motion of the arm
Flapping motion of the hands when arms are extended
Restlessness and intense urge to move
Slow, writhing movements of the fingers

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CJD is a neurodegenerative condition caused by prions (misfolded proteins that transmit their misfolded shape onto normal variants of the protein) demonstrating an increase in ꞵ-sheet structures. These ꞵ-sheets are resistant to proteolysis and form insoluble plaques that deposit in the brain. These plaques have a toxic effect on surrounding neurons, leading to neural cell death and development of multiple “holes” in the brain. As a result, CJD produces a characteristic spongy appearance of the brain termed spongiform encephalopathy. There are four types of CJD: familial (due to PRNP gene mutation), variant (due to consumption of contaminated animal meat), iatrogenic (due to medical procedures such as corneal transplants), and sporadic (appears without clear cause).  

Patients with CJD have long incubation periods but once symptoms manifest, individuals develop rapidly progressive dementia within weeks to months. It is classically associated with ataxia (lack of coordination of voluntary movements) and myoclonus (jerking movement of a muscle group). In CJD, the myoclonus is usually generalized and can be triggered when the person is startled by a loud noise -- the response is therefore termed “startle myoclonus.” There is no effective treatment for CJD, and it is uniformly fatal. Death commonly occurs within one year of symptom onset.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden involuntary contraction of muscles after a loud sound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Unilateral, violent, flailing motion of the arm:
Incorrect: Hemiballismus is characterized by sudden, wild flailing of an extremity. It occurs following a stroke affecting the subthalamic nucleus. However, a stroke would not account for the spongiform brain tissue seen in the above image.
❌ Flapping motion of the hands when arms are extended:
Incorrect: Asterixis is characterized by a “flapping” tremor of the hands that occurs with extension of the wrists. It is associated with hepatic encephalopathy and can also be seen in conditions causing liver cirrhosis (e.g., chronic alcohol use, viral hepatitis, Wilson disease). 
❌ Restlessness and intense urge to move:
Incorrect: Akathisia presents as an inability to sit still with a constant urge to move. It can be seen in patients chronically using first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol. 
❌ Slow, writhing movements of the fingers:
Incorrect: Athetosis presents as a slow, snake-like writhing movement, especially of the fingers. It can be seen in patients with Huntington disease. However, Huntington disease would not account for the spongiform brain tissue seen in the above image.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the clinic due to progressive paranoia and personality changes for the past 2 months. The patient’s partner reports that he started acting oddly 2 months ago. He blamed her for infidelity multiple times without any reason. The patient’s partner also noted that he hasn't been sleeping well lately. The patient has been a lawyer for many years and recently has been receiving bad reviews regarding his performance. There is no family history of any significant medical conditions. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and suspicious. Nystagmus is present bilaterally. The patient occasionally kicks the table involuntarily. When the doctor claps his hands, the patient is startled and jumps in his seat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of rapidly progressive (1 month) cognitive decline, insomnia, personality changes, and “startle myoclonus” all raise concern for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).  

CJD cardinal signs include rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus (“startle myoclonus”) and ataxia. Other manifestations include aphasia, apraxia, pyramidal signs (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia), and extrapyramidal signs (e.g., bradykinesia, dystonia, rigidity). Myoclonus, the hallmark of the condition (especially provoked by startle), is present in more than 90% of CJD cases. Myoclonus is a brief, involuntary, jerking of a muscle or group of muscles caused by muscular contractions or inhibitions. Muscular contractions manifest as positive myoclonus, while muscular inhibitions produce negative myoclonus such as asterixis. Myoclonus can be divided as follows:  

  •  Physiologic: A normal phenomenon seen in healthy individuals. Common examples include jerks during sleep and hiccups.  
  •  Essential: The myoclonus is typically the only and main clinical finding (i.e. an "essential" phenomenon). Patients usually experience mild disabilities. The condition may be hereditary or sporadic. 
  •  Symptomatic (secondary): Myoclonus secondary to other conditions such as encephalopathy or neurodegenerative disorders.  
  • Epileptic: Refers to myoclonus in the setting of epilepsy.


Option Analysis

❌ Frontotemporal dementia :
Incorrect: FTD is characterized by early behavioral changes (due to frontal lobe degeneration) that can present as disinhibition (e.g., kissing strangers, public urination), apathy, and hyperorality (which can manifest as increased smoking habits). Although this patient is presenting with behavioral changes, the myoclonus and nystagmus seen on physical examination suggests a different diagnosis. 
❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease presents with a slow, progressive course of prominent memory impairment. Motor signs would be abnormal, especially considering this patient’s symptoms began only months ago.
❌ Huntington’s disease :
Incorrect: The diagnosis of Huntington’s disease (HD) is based upon the presence of typical clinical features (e.g., chorea, dementia, depression), a family history of the disease, and genetic confirmation of the trinucleotide gene expansion. Although this patient is presenting with signs of dementia and motor symptoms (e.g. myoclonus), the lack of family history makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Normal pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of “wet, wacky and wobbly,” which describes the urinary incontinence, dementia, and gait disorder seen in this condition. Although this patient exhibits dementia, the clinical presentation (e.g., rapidly progressing dementia, startle myoclonus) suggests a different etiology.
✅ Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to increased blinking and occasional jaw pain. She describes increased blinking and episodic closure of the eyelids when exposed to bright light. On one occasion, her eyes closed during driving, and she almost had an accident. She is very concerned about her ability to drive. In addition, she also noticed that her jaw occasionally clenches for several minutes, causing mild pain. Medical history is unremarkable, and medications are oral contraceptives and multivitamins. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol or recreational drugs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy patient, who is presenting with increased blinking, forceful eye closure triggered by bright light, and mild jaw spasm, likely has blepharospasm, a type of focal dystonia.  

Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary, sustained or intermittent muscle contractions that results in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. Dystonia may be idiopathic, part of another condition (e.g. Parkinson disease), acquired (e.g., stroke, medications) or genetic (e.g. autosomal recessive primary isolated dystonia). The neuropathological mechanism in isolated dystonia remains unclear, but the lack of cell degeneration implies that isolated dystonia is a dynamic disorder, caused by abnormal cell function.  

Blepharospasm is a type of focal dystonia involving the orbicularis oculi muscles and periocular muscles. Clinical findings include increased blinking and spasms of involuntary eye closure. The symptoms are typically bilateral, synchronous, and symmetric or asymmetric. Patients often complain of spasms under conditions of bright light or stress, such as driving. Blepharospasm may be accompanied by pain or irritation of the lower face and/or jaw, as seen in this patient. The diagnosis of isolated dystonia is based mainly on clinical features, while other types of dystonia may require additional testing (e.g. genetic testing). Treatment usually consists of levodopa, trihexyphenidyl, tetrabenazine, botulinum toxin injections and deep brain stimulation, depending on the underlying cause, the severity and responsiveness to treatment.  



Option Analysis

❌ Temporal arteritis:
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) typically presents with unilateral pain, constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, fatigue), and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., elevated ESR and CRP); patients are also usually above the age of 50. This patient’s age, increased bilateral blinking, and the absence of other signs favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Myoclonus:
Incorrect: Myoclonus is a brief, involuntary, twitch of a muscle or group of muscles caused by muscular contractions or inhibitions. Myoclonus is often described as jerks, shakes, or spasms. Myoclonus may be physiologic, such as jerks during sleep or hiccups, or pathologic, such as epileptic myoclonus. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Dystonia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Trigeminal neuralgia:
Incorrect: Trigeminal neuralgia is a neuropathic disorder that typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, “shock-like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving).  Trigeminal neuralgia is not associated with increased blinking or forceful shutting of the eye lids, and the pain usually is much more severe. 
❌ Tics :
Incorrect: Tics are brief, sudden, rapid, and intermittent movements (motor tics) or sounds (vocal tics) that can be repetitive and stereotypic. Dystonic tics are more prolonged and are similar to dystonia; however, tics are typically associated with an urge that is relieved by performing the tic. Instead, this patient is bothered by the symptoms and lacks a history of repetitive and stereotypic tics, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of involuntary movements that have progressed insidiously and are now interfering with walking. Medical history is unremarkable; she takes only an oral contraceptive. The patient’s father, who passed away, had similar symptoms when he was 50, with rapid cognitive decline. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient suddenly makes rapid and unpredictable contractions affecting the distal hands. The movements are not repetitive or rhythmic. Which of the following best describes this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with chorea, and in light of the father's medical history, she most likely has Huntington disease.   

Huntington disease is an autosomal dominant caused by trinucleotide (CAG) repeat expansion in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4. Symptoms typically present between ages 20 and 50 and include chorea, athetosis, aggression, depression, and dementia. Chorea is defined as a rapid, involuntary, arrhythmic, disorganized movement with variable speed, timing, and direction. Most commonly, it involves the distal extremities, but it also affects the trunk and face. Athetosis is a slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement of the fingers, hands, toes, and less commonly, the arms, legs, neck, and tongue. The term "choreoathetosis" is used when chorea and athetosis coexist.  

The structures that have been associated with chorea include the putamen, caudate nucleus, subthalamic nucleus, thalamus, and their interconnecting pathways. The basal ganglia system is important in regulating movement. Damage or malfunction of these structures disrupts the balance between the indirect and direct pathways in the basal ganglia circuitry, leading to excessive dopaminergic activity. Disruption to the indirect pathway results in loss of inhibition to the globus pallidus which in turn allows hyperkinetic movements to occur. Chorea, athetosis, and ballism often coexist in the same patient and are considered to be a part of the choreiform spectrum.    



Option Analysis

❌ Akathisia:
Incorrect: Akathisia refers to an inner sense of restlessness that manifests as an intense desire to move. The restlessness is typically generalized but may be more prominent in the legs. Akathisia is associated with the use of neuroleptic (dopamine blocking) drugs, which are not used by the patient.  
❌ Dystonia:
Incorrect: Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder typified by involuntary muscle contractions that may result in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. Writer's dystonia, also known as writer's cramp, is an example of task-specific hand dystonia elicited by writing. Instead, this patient’s presentation is consistent with chorea.
✅ Chorea:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hemiballismus:
Incorrect: Hemiballismus refers to involuntary, large amplitude, flinging movements of the proximal limbs. Any condition that damages the basal ganglia circuitry and subthalamic nucleus may result in contralateral hemiballismus. Hemiballismus can be a part of the choreiform spectrum present in Huntington disease; however, this patient’s movement is distal and therefore more consistent with chorea.  
❌ Tardive dyskinesia:
Incorrect: Tardive dyskinesia refers to involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, trunk, and extremities that occur after prolonged treatment with dopaminergic antagonist medications (e.g. antipsychotics). This patient’s presentation is more consistent with chorea, and she has no history of antipsychotic use.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician due to difficulty walking. The patient describes his gait as though his feet are “glued to the ground.” Additionally, he has been having difficulty finishing his daily crossword puzzle, which he attributes to impaired concentration. He has not experienced headaches, nausea, vomiting, or visual changes, but he has experienced episodes during which he has a sudden urge to urinate. The patient frequently has difficulty making it to the bathroom due to his gait dysfunction. Past medical history is notable for a subarachnoid hemorrhage that occurred several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient’s Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 22/30 (normal: ≥ 24). Physical examination is notable for a broad-based and shuffling gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow between ventricles
Loss of brain parenchyma with an apparent increase in cerebrospinal fluid

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a triad of urinary incontinence, gait abnormalities, and imapired cognitive function. He likely has normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage.

CSF is produced in the lateral ventricles by the choroid plexus and then flows into the third and fourth ventricles. CSF is reabsorbed into the systemic circulation primarily across the arachnoid villi of the sagittal sinus. If CSF reabsorption is interrupted, normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) can occur. Most causes are idiopathic, but potential secondary causes include previous subarachnoid hemorrhage or meningitis that resulted in fibrosis of the arachnoid granulations.

As CSF accumulates within the ventricular system, there is compression and dysfunction of motor areas in the frontal lobe and periventricular white matter tracts. This pressure can contribute to various clinical symptoms. The three characteristic symptoms of NPH can be remembered with the phrase “wet (urinary incontinence), wacky (dementia) and wobbly (impaired gait)”:

  •  Gait abnormalities are the predominant clinical sign. Patients often have a broad-based gait with short steps, which is also termed “magnetic” or “glued” gait.  
  •  Dementia often manifests with decreased concentration, apathy, and impaired executive functioning.  
  •  Urinary incontinence often presents as increased urgency and frequency. It is caused by frontal lobe compression and a subsequent inability to suppress the voiding reflex.
Diagnosis of NPH is made with head imaging showing ventriculomegaly. Confirmatory testing involves a lumbar puncture, which would demonstrate a slightly elevated opening pressure and improvement of symptoms after CSF removal. Definitive treatment involves placing a cerebral shunt to drain the excess CSF.



Option Analysis

✅ Impaired cerebrospinal fluid reabsorption:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased cerebrospinal fluid production:
Incorrect: Increased cerebrospinal fluid production is rare but can be seen in choroid plexus papilloma. This benign tumor of the choroid plexus results in increased CSF production, causing symptoms of intracranial hypertension (e.g., headache, nausea). However, this patient’s symptoms are better explained by another condition.
❌ Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow between ventricles:
Incorrect: Non-communicating hydrocephalus is characterized by impaired flow of CSF between ventricles. The condition can be caused by brain tumors, current subarachnoid or intraventricular hemorrhage, and inflammation following recovery from meningitis. Symptoms are secondary to elevated intracranial pressure and include headaches, nausea, and vomiting.
❌ Loss of brain parenchyma with an apparent increase in cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo describes a condition wherein loss of brain tissue makes the ventricles larger and appear as if there is increased cerebrospinal fluid volume. The condition is a misnomer, as it is not true hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is associated with Alzheimer dementia, which causes profound cortical atrophy.
❌ Normal aging:
Incorrect: Normal aging can cause degenerative joint disease and manifest with gait impairment. However, this patient’s constellation of urinary incontinence, gait abnormalities, and imapired cognitive function is more indicative of a different underlying pathology.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her partner due to recent behavioral changes. The symptoms began four months ago. According to the partner, the patient would be doing daily activities, such as chopping vegetables, and she would abruptly stop and appear to "blank out,” followed by resumption of the activity. Additionally, the patient recently got lost in the parking lot of a nearby grocery store that she has been visiting for many years. Past medical history is noncontributory. She does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals rigidity in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Tremors, which began two months ago, are present in both hands at rest. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Two very similar causes of irreversible dementia are dementia with Lewy bodies (DBL) and Parkinson disease. Both are alphas-synucleinopathies and can cause dementia and Parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia). However, differentiation can be made based on whether dementia occurs prior to or at the same time as Parkinsonism. For instance, this patient who is presenting with dementia, fluctuating cognition, and Parkinsonism at roughly the same time likely has DBL. In contrast, Parkinson disease typically has Parkinsonism that predates cognitive impairment by >1 year.

Clinical features of DBL vary, but all patients present with signs of dementia. There are early impairments in attention as well as executive and visuospatial function, and memory is affected later in the disease course. Moreover, a likely diagnosis of DLB requires ≥2 of the following core clinical features:  

  1.  Cognitive fluctuations: Fluctuations in cognition can present as a brief decline in ability to perform an activity of daily living or can be dramatic enough to mimic a stroke or seizure 
  2.  Visual hallucinations: Seeing animals or people (e.g. deceased loved ones) 
  3.  REM sleep behavior disorder: Dream enactment behavior occurs after loss of REM sleep atonia. It is a common prodromal sign and can predate symptoms of dementia by many years. 
  4.  Parkinsonism: Tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability must occur at the same time or after dementia begins.  



Option Analysis

✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Parkinson disease dementia:
Incorrect: Parkinson disease and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) are similar conditions, with the exception being that Parkinson disease has Parkinsonism (e.g., tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia) that predates cognitive impairment by >1 year. In contrast, patients with DLB have symptoms of cognitive impairment and Parkinsonism that emerge at roughly the same time.
❌ Alzheimer disease:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease presents with prominent memory impairment early in the disease course. Fluctuating cognition and motor signs would be abnormal, especially considering this patient’s symptoms began just several months ago. 
❌ Vascular dementia:
Incorrect: Vascular dementia classically presents with a stepwise and gradual decline in neurocognitive cognition. The condition occurs due to recurrent small and large cerebral vessel disease. Patients typically have risk factors for cardiovascular disease, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, which are absent in this patient. 
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia presents with early changes in personality and behavior that manifest as apathy and/or disinhibition. Motor deficits are seen much later in the disease course, and they would not manifest within several months of onset of dementia signs, such as in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the clinic accompanied by her daughter for a follow-up appointment for cognitive decline. During the past 2 years, the daughter says the patient has been having difficulty managing her accounts and is often confused. She has some “good days” when she manages the household and some “bad days” when she is confused and needs assistance. The patient’s partner passed away 3 years ago from a myocardial infarction, and in the past few months, her daughter found the patient talking to him as though he is in the room. About 6 months ago, the patient started having a mild resting tremor in her right hand. Since then, the patient’s movements have slowed down, and she often loses balance. Vitals are within normal limits. No orthostasis is seen. On physical examination, the patient has a flat affect, and a resting tremor is noted in the right hand. The patient walks slowly with small steps and has a kyphotic posture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with progressive dementia, cognitive fluctuation (“good” and “bad” days), and recent onset of parkinsonian signs, all favoring the diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB).  

DLB is a common type of degenerative dementia. In addition to dementia, a patient with DLB must have at least 2 of the 4 core features, including:

  •  cognitive fluctuations 
  •  visual hallucinations 
  •  rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder 
  • parkinsonism, which is characterized by the 4 clinical signs of tremor, rigidity, akinesia, and postural instability (TRAP) 
Patients typically show an early decline in executive function (e.g. calculations), and visuoperceptual ability (e.g. missing traffic signs). The diagnosis of DLB is based upon the presence of core clinical features, history, and physical examination. MRI will likely show nonspecific diffuse cortical atrophy. The hallmark of the disease is the presence of Lewy bodies on pathological examination of the brain; these are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions containing aggregated alpha-synuclein in the deep cortical layers.  

The differentiation of Parkinson disease from DLB is typically based on the timeline in which symptoms occur. If Parkinsonian motor symptoms are present for more than 1 year before dementia, the diagnosis is Parkinson disease dementia, whereas if dementia occurs concomitantly with or before parkinsonian motor signs, or no more than a year after onset, it is considered dementia with Lewy bodies.    

Several neurodegenerative conditions may present with the classic signs of PD (e.g., tremor, rigidity) which may be hard to differentiate. These conditions are often referred to as Parkinson-plus syndromes and include multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and DLB. Each has unique features that may help in establishing the diagnosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Progressive supranuclear palsy:
Incorrect: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism, loss of balance and vertical eye palsy. The absence of vertical eye palsy and marked personality changes favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: If Parkinson motor symptoms are present for more than 1 year before dementia, the diagnosis is Parkinson disease dementia. If dementia appears before or together with the motor symptoms, or less than a year after, the diagnosis is considered dementia with Lewy bodies. This patient had signs of dementia a year and a half before motor signs. 
❌ Frontotemporal dementia:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia, formerly known as Pick disease, is characterized by early personality and behavior changes or aphasia. Patients with frontotemporal dementia may also have associated movement disorders (e.g. parkinsonism). This patient has not had marked personality changes. Additionally, parkinsonism, if present, occurs very late in the course of the disease. 
✅ Dementia with Lewy bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple system atrophy:
Incorrect: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a group of neurodegenerative syndromes with similar underlying brain pathology that are characterized by parkinsonism, autonomic dysfunction, cerebellar abnormalities, and corticospinal degeneration. This patient has no autonomic dysfunction (e.g. orthostatic hypotension), which favors another diagnosis. Additionally, in contrast to idiopathic Parkinson disease, patients with MSA have preserved cognitive function.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of trisomy 21 comes to the physician for evaluation of worsening cognition. The patient has a moderate intellectual disability at baseline; he has some difficulty with executive functioning and attention span. He lives independently and has been able to work as a store clerk for several years; however, he was recently released from work due to declining performance and inability to remember tasks. The patient recalls having gotten lost in the store while restocking shelves. He drinks 1-2 beers each evening, and he does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. The patient also participates in a local rugby league, but he has found it increasingly difficult to remember practice times. His grandfather died from frontotemporal dementia at the age of 78. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for upward slanting eyelids and bilateral transverse palmar creases. No gait or motor abnormalities are noted. Which of the following risk factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s cognitive decline?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with declining cognitive function and an inability to perform tasks of daily living (e.g., getting lost in familiar places, forgetting practice times) in the setting of trisomy 21. These findings are concerning for Alzheimer disease (AD).  

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is associated with early-onset AD, which is defined as cases occurring before the age of 65. Early-onset AD accounts for 5-10% of cases. The association exists because patients with trisomy 21 have three copies of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (located on chromosome 21). The extra copy of APP causes overproduction of the protein, which subsequently undergoes abnormal enzymatic cleavage into beta-amyloid peptides and aggregates to form insoluble plaques.   

These plaques decrease the number of synapses and alter neuronal functioning. Patients with trisomy 21 typically have AD brain pathology by the age of 40 and approximately two-thirds will develop dementia by the age of 60.  

Additionally, mutations in PSEN-1 and PSEN-2 genes have been linked to early-onset AD. These genes encode for presenilin-1 and presenilin-2, which are both protein subunits of gamma-secretase. Mutations in these genes change the location where gamma secretase cleaves APP, resulting in the production of different sized beta amyloid molecules, which aggregate into plaques.  

Option Analysis

✅ Aneuploidy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Alzheimer dementia is more prevalent in older populations, with most patients experiencing initial symptoms (e.g., cognitive decline, impaired ability to perform tasks of daily living) after the age of 60. This patient’s age is an unlikely risk factor for developing dementia. 
❌ Family history :
Incorrect: Although frontotemporal dementia (FTD) may have a genetic component, patients typically present first with behavioral changes (e.g., social disinhibition, apathy). In contrast, this patient is presenting with declining memory and an inability to perform tasks of daily living, which is more concerning for Alzheimer disease. Furthermore, this patient’s underlying genetic condition puts him at a substantially higher risk of developing Alzheimer disease.
❌ Substance use:
Incorrect: Significant alcohol use for many years can result in alcohol-related dementia. This patient is drinking 1-2 beers daily, which is on the higher end of the recommended range. However, this amount of alcohol intake is unlikely to be the cause of the patient’s significant cognitive impairments. 
❌ Physical contact sports :
Incorrect: Repeated concussive and subconcussive blows to the head can cause chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE); this condition has been shown to occur in boxers and football players. Patients may present with significant cognitive decline, as in the case of this patient. However, patients often manifest with additional behavioral abnormalities (e.g., aggression, paranoia) and psychiatric disturbances (e.g., depression, anxiety, suicidality), which are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to his physician, accompanied by his partner, for evaluation of “abnormal movements that occur while he sleeps.” Symptoms began around four months ago. According to the partner, the patient has on multiple occasions exhibited various movements, such as throwing a ball or punching invisible objects, while asleep. The partner has been sleeping in the guest bedroom for the past several weeks to avoid getting hurt by him. The patient is unaware of these activities, but he recalls vivid dreams of playing baseball and fighting off home invaders. Past medical history is noncontributory. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 138/87 mmHg, and pulse is 71 beats/min. The physician orders a polysomnogram, which reveals REM sleep without atonia. Which of the following findings is this patient likely to develop in the future?

choices.text: Episodes of disinhibited behavior in public

questions.solution:
Dementia with Lewy bodies (DBL) is a neurodegenerative condition that results in cerebral atrophy, especially of the frontal lobe. The condition is characterized by the accumulation of Lewy bodies, which are composed of alpha-synuclein. Alpha-synuclein is a protein found at presynaptic terminals and is involved in neurotransmitter release. In times of increased oxidative stress and under pathologic conditions, alpha-synuclein undergoes a structural change, forming oligomers and beta sheet structures which ultimately deposit as Lewy bodies. The accumulation of Lewy bodies leads to myelin and glial dysfunction with subsequent neuronal degeneration. On histological analysis, Lewy bodies are seen as round, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions inside neurons.  

Clinically, DBL can cause REM sleep behavior disorders, wherein patients physically act out dreams since they lack the muscle atonia that characterizes normal REM sleep. Additional symptoms include fluctuating cognitive function (characterized by variation in attention and episodes of drowsiness), visual hallucinations, and Parkinsonism (muscle rigidity, tremors, bradykinesia). In some patients, the abnormalities with REM sleep can precede the other symptoms by several years. This phenomenon likely arises due to early deposition of alpha-synuclein in the pontine and medullary nuclei, which control REM sleep.  




Option Analysis

✅ Visual hallucinations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Episodes of disinhibited behavior in public:
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior. It occurs due to degeneration of the frontal lobe and impaired executive functioning. Early signs of FTD include failure to observe social etiquette and disinhibition (e.g., hyperorality, hypersexual behavior). This patient is presenting with a REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a prodromal phase for another neurodegenerative condition.  
❌ Memory loss and confabulation:
Incorrect: Korsakoff syndrome may develop in patients chronic alcohol use due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency results in decreased cerebral glucose metabolism and neuronal injury. Patients typically exhibit anterograde and retrograde amnesia with compensatory confabulations, wherein they fabricate stories to fill lapses in memory. 
❌ Language deficits and spatial disorientation:
Incorrect: Alzheimer disease (AD) is characterized by cognitive decline, which results in a loss of temporal and spatial orientation as well as language deficits. This patient is currently presenting with a REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a prodromal phase for another neurodegenerative condition.
❌ Myoclonus and seizures:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion-mediated, rapidly progressive dementia. Classic clinical features include myoclonus (involuntary contraction of muscles) brought about by loud sounds, which is termed “startle myoclonus.” Sleep disturbances are also common in CFD, but they typically manifest as hypersomnia or insomnia. REM sleep behavior disorders would be highly unusual in CJD.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic due to progressive dizziness for the past month. The patient states the dizziness typically occurs several seconds after standing up from a seated position. The patient states he also has had nocturia, urinary urgency, and erectile dysfunction for the past few months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), and pulse is 80/min. Blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg when the patient is in a recumbent position and 90/70 mmHg when standing. Ocular movements are normal. There is increased rigidity of both arms and legs. On gait evaluation, the patient strides in small steps and fails to fully lift his feet from the floor. The Mini-Mental State Examination result is 26/30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, incontinence, and diffuse rigidity, all favoring the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy (MSA).  

MSA refers to a group of neurodegenerative syndromes (including Shy-Drager syndrome) that share similar brain pathology and are characterized by autonomic dysfunction, cerebellar abnormalities, parkinsonism, and corticospinal degeneration in varying combinations. MSA can be further divided into two subtypes: MSA with predominant parkinsonism (MSA-P) and MSA with predominant cerebellar ataxia (MSA-C). At the early stages of the condition, Parkinson disease can be difficult to distinguish from MSA. However, in contrast to Parkinson disease, MSA patients typically have preserved cognitive function. The levodopa responsiveness test can help to establish the diagnosis; while Parkinson patients tend to have an excellent response to levodopa-carbidopa, MSA patients have a poor response to levodopa therapy.  

The diagnosis of MSA is based upon clinical features, and no laboratory or imaging studies are diagnostic. Neuroimaging is often non-revealing or equivocal but can assist in excluding other conditions. When present, atrophy can be seen in the basal ganglia circuit (e.g., putamen, globus pallidus). Treatment is dependent on the signs and symptoms. In general, despite the poor response to levodopa, patients do better with levodopa treatment than without it. Chronic orthostatic hypotension is managed with fludrocortisone acetate.  


 

Option Analysis

❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Many features seen in this patient can be explained by multiple sclerosis (MS); however, it is rare for MS to present after the age of 50, and other characteristic features such as visual disturbances and paresthesias would be expected. Additionally, rigidity (a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch, meaning that it is more noticeable with fast movements) is rare in MS, and most patients instead exhibit spasticity (non-velocity-dependent increase in resistance to passive movement, meaning that it does not vary with speed of movement of muscle groups involved).  
❌ Parkinson disease:
Incorrect: Although this patient is presenting with some of the classic signs of Parkinson disease, the predominance of autonomic symptoms favors the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy. 
✅ Multiple system atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal-pressure hydrocephalus:
Incorrect: Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is an idiopathic condition characterized by the expansion of ventricles and distortion of the corona radiata fibers. Patients typically present with a classic triad of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia (typically described as a “magnetic gait”), and cognitive dysfunction. However, in this case, the predominance of autonomic symptoms and the preserved cognition (>24 on mini-mental status exam) favor the diagnosis of multiple system atrophy. Lastly, diffuse rigidity is not typically seen in NPH.
❌ Progressive supranuclear palsy:
Incorrect: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by personality and behavior changes, parkinsonism, loss of balance and vertical eye palsy. Although some of the features seen in this patient can also be seen in PSP, the absence of vertical eye palsy and the signs of autonomic dysfunction favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician’s office due to a recent fall and the feeling of unsteadiness. The patient fell 2 days ago when going down the stairs but did not experience any head trauma. The patient’s partner reports that the patient has been acting differently for the past several months and is often anxious. The patient is healthy with no significant past medical history, and he does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is mild hyperkyphosis, and the patient is walking slowly. The muscle tone is increased bilaterally. There is a mild tremor on the right hand during rest which disappears on a finger-to-nose test. The patient is started on appropriate therapy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on examination of a patient’s brain with this condition?

choices.text: Atrophy of putamen and caudate nucleus
Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions within the neuron's cytoplasm
Basophilic fibrillary structures within the neuronal cytoplasm

questions.solution:
This patient has hyperkyphosis, postural instability, hypokinesia (small steps), resting tremor, and personality changes (anxiety or depression), a presentation consistent with Parkinson disease (PD).  

Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions in the cytoplasm of neurons are consistent with Lewy bodies, which are considered the pathological hallmark of PD, along with degeneration of dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra. In PD, dopamine depletion in the substantia nigra and nigrostriatal pathway ultimately results in excess inhibition of the thalamus and decreased excitatory input to the motor cortex, which manifests as bradykinesia and other signs of parkinsonism.  

The cardinal signs of PD include a pill-rolling tremor at rest, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, and postural instability (this can be remembered with the mnemonic TRAP). Other common signs are hypomimia (reduced degree of facial expression, also known as masked facies), dysphagia, micrographia, stooped posture/kyphosis, shuffling gait, and dementia later on in the disease course.

PD has no cure, and treatment is aimed to control symptoms and delay disease progression. The pharmacologic treatment is individualized based on the patient's characteristics and the disease progression. The main drug classes include MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline), amantadine (increases dopamine release), dopamine agonists, and levodopa/carbidopa. Anticholinergic drugs are also used mainly for tremor relief.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Atrophy of putamen and caudate nucleus :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Huntington disease, which typically presents with personality changes, such as aggression, depression, and dementia, as well as movement disorders, including chorea and athetosis. Imaging or autopsy of the brain typically shows ex vacuo ventriculomegaly, meaning the ventricles look enlarged when in reality the brain itself is atrophied. 
❌ Multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with vascular dementia, a condition caused by multiple infarcts and/or chronic ischemia.  The condition is typically seen in patients with longstanding cardiovascular conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes), which this patient lacks. Common presenting symptoms include a stepwise decline in cognitive ability and late-onset memory impairment. 
✅ Eosinophilic sphere-shaped inclusions within the neuron's cytoplasm:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Basophilic fibrillary structures within the neuronal cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer depicts neurofibrillary tangles, a common finding in Alzheimer disease (AD). These tangles are made of accumulated hyperphosphorylated tau protein. Alzheimer disease typically presents with early memory loss and dementia. While motor signs (e.g., pyramidal, extrapyramidal) do occur in patients with AD, these are usually late-stage findings.
❌ Round inclusions of hyperphosphorylated proteins:
Incorrect: Round inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins or ubiquitinated TDP-43 can be seen in frontotemporal dementia, which is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior in addition to aphasia. On imaging, frontotemporal lobe degeneration is often seen.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining brain biopsies from a patient who died from a neurodegenerative condition following an episode of aspiration pneumonia. A tissue sample from the patient is demonstrated below:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Further staining reveals patchy red plaques that become yellow when viewed under polarized light. Which of the following clinical courses was most likely seen in this patient?

choices.text: Early memory loss followed by behavioral changes
Early behavioral changes followed by memory loss
Rapidly progressive memory loss and behavioral changes

questions.solution:
