The brain biopsy shows numerous plaques that stain with Congo red and demonstrate birefringence when viewed under polarized light. As a result, this biopsy sample was likely from a patient who had Alzheimer disease (AD). In AD, deposition of extracellular beta-amyloid protein plaques (yellow circles) and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles causes neuronal degeneration. Most patients are in their 70-80s when symptoms develop. The disease typically has three phases:

  1.  The asymptomatic phase is when the molecular pathology of AD is present in the brain, but clinical symptoms have not yet manifested. 
  2.  The predementia phase is characterized by mild cognitive impairment. There is a gradual onset of memory impairment without significant deficits in other cognitive domains or daily functioning. This phase differs from normal aging because the memory impairment is greater than expected for the individual’s age.
  3. The dementia phase is when individuals develop significant memory loss, followed by slow, gradual loss of the other cognitive functions (e.g, language, visuospatial skills, executive functions). There are two main types of memory: episodic memory (memory of events) and semantic memory (memory of words and vocabulary). Early on, episodic memory is impaired and semantic memory remains intact. With disease progression, both episodic and semantic memory become impaired. Behavioral changes also occur in advanced stages, resulting in apathy, agitation, irritability, and aggression. 




Option Analysis

✅ Early memory loss followed by behavioral changes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Early behavioral changes followed by memory loss:
Incorrect: This clinical course is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia. Initial neuronal degeneration in the frontal lobe results in social disinhibition and behavioral changes. As neuronal damage and loss progresses, there are profound memory deficits. However, histopathology in patients with frontotemporal dementia would demonstrate Pick bodies (cytoplasmic inclusions of aggregated tau proteins) and hyperphosphorylated TDP-43, which are not present in this patient’s tissue sample.
❌ Rapidly progressive memory loss and behavioral changes:
Incorrect: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CFD) is caused by prions and results in a rapidly progressive dementia. Histopathology would demonstrate spongiform degeneration as a result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles.
❌ Mild decline in cognitive functioning:
Incorrect: A mild decline in cognitive functioning is seen as a result of normal aging. Patients may have mild cortical atrophy, but the histopathological findings in this patient are more consistent with those of Alzheimer disease.
❌ Stepwise deterioration in cognition:
Incorrect: A stepwise decline in cognition is typically observed in patients with vascular dementia. The condition arises due to cerebral tissue ischemia and can be due to atherosclerosis, thrombosis, or vasculopathy.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner due to worsening insomnia and cognitive impairment for the past 3 months. According to the husband, the patient had previously been able to drive to the grocery store and play racquetball. However, she is no longer able to complete these activities on her own. The patient has no history of psychiatric conditions, but her mother died from Alzheimer disease in her 80s. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical exam reveals ataxic gait and an inability to follow multi-step instructions.  When a nearby door is shut loudly, the patient is startled, causing her arms to clench involuntarily. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid
Enlarged ventricles with normal sulci on MRI of the brain
Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography
Metabolic disorders in the frontal and temporal lobes on PET scan
Atrophy of the mammillary bodies on MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative illness that causes death within 1 year of symptom onset. Patients typically experience a prodromal phase characterized by vague, nonspecific symptoms, such as headaches, fatigue, and sleep disorders. Neuropsychiatric symptoms are consistently seen and manifest as dementia, behavioral abnormalities, and deficits involving higher cortical function (e.g. aphasia). Additionally, a characteristic physical exam finding seen in patients with CJD is startle myoclonus, wherein jerking or clenching movements of a muscle group are triggered by a loud sound (e.g. door slamming shut). Work-up of CJD involves several different modalities, including the following:  

  •  MRI imaging is the best initial test. Brain MRI excludes other potential causes of dementia and also can identify findings suggestive of CJD. On brain MRI, CJD classically presents with enhancement of the basal ganglia and thalamus. 
  •  Periodic sharp wave complexes are the hallmark EEG finding of CJD. The fusion of dendritic membranes of affected neurons results in increased electrotonic coupling and synchronized bursting activity. 
  •  Detection of protein 14-3-3 in cerebrospinal fluid is classically seen in patients with CJD, and it occurs due to acute neuronal damage. 
Ultimately, definitive diagnosis requires a post-mortem brain biopsy demonstrating spongiform encephalopathy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlarged ventricles with normal sulci on MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of “wet, wacky and wobbly,” which describes the urinary incontinence, dementia, and gait disorder seen in this condition. Although this patient exhibits a gait disorder and dementia, her other clinical features (e.g., rapidly progressing dementia, startle myoclonus) suggest a different etiology. 
❌ Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography:
Incorrect: Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalography (EEG) are characteristic of absence seizures, which are usually seen in pediatric patients. This condition is characterized by multiple, short periods of impaired consciousness with intact body tone. 
❌ Metabolic disorders in the frontal and temporal lobes on PET scan :
Incorrect: Frontotemporal dementia classically presents with early personality changes (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, irritability) followed by reduced cognitive functioning. MRI typically shows atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes, as well as frontotemporal hypoperfusion or hypometabolism, which can be visualized on a PET scan.
❌ Atrophy of the mammillary bodies on MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is seen in patients with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder or severe malnourishment. The condition occurs due to destruction and atrophy of the mammillary bodies. Patients typically present with confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and in severe cases, permanent amnesia.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to behavior problems and declining academic performance. He used to do well in school but during the past year and a half, he started receiving Cs and Ds in his classes and having social problems. The patient’s teachers report he disrupts classmates, cannot sit still, and makes “funny noises.” The parents mention that he used to have a lot of friends but now constantly gets into fights because his classmates make fun of his behavior. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the child blinks constantly, shrugs the shoulders, and occasionally grunts. When the child is asked to stop these movements, he can suppress them for a few moments, then recommences. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with academic decline, vocal tics (grunting), and motor tics (blinking and shoulder shrugging) that have been present for more than 1 year, all favoring the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome. The disruptive behavior is most likely due to concurrent attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, present in up to 60% of the cases.  

Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to disturbances in the cortico-striatal-thalamic (mesolimbic) circuit, which results in disinhibition of the limbic and motor systems. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition and are defined as sudden, brief, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Provisional tic disorder :
Incorrect:  Provisional tic disorder, also known as transient tics, is a type of motor disorder in which a child experiences involuntary motor and/or verbal tics for less than one year. This occurs in otherwise healthy children and spontaneously remits in a few weeks or months. This child has been experiencing symptoms for more than 1 year. 
❌ Persistent Tic Disorder:
Incorrect: Persistent tic disorder, also known as chronic tic disorder, is characterized by either motor tics OR vocal tics, but not both, for more than 1 year and before 18 years of age. This patient is exhibiting both vocal and motor tics. 
✅ Tourette syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epileptic automatisms:
Incorrect: Automatisms are nonpurposeful, brief, unconscious, stereotyped behaviors that often accompany certain types of epilepsy, such as complex partial seizures. These include finger rubbing, lip-smacking, chewing, etc.. Patients are amnestic to their automatisms. This child has vocal and motor tics that he can suppress when asked, making this diagnosis very unlikely. 
❌ Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by brief (less than one minute) attacks of choreoathetosis, dystonia, or both that occur with sudden changes in movement, such as getting up from a seated position. Movements are often unilateral and consciousness is retained. This child’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to academic decline and bizarre behavior for the past 6 months. He used to be a straight-A student, but during the past 2 years, he has been failing exams and repeatedly getting in trouble with teachers. The teachers report that he speaks out of turn, interrupts other students, and makes inappropriate gestures. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is constantly blinking and clears his throat frequently. Occasionally, the patient points the middle finger at the doctor, and doing so appears to cause the patient distress. The parents are embarrassed and concerned about their son's demeanor. Which of the following best describes this patient's behavior?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with academic decline, vocal tics (clears throat), and motor tics (blinking, obscene gestures) that have been present for more than 1 year, all favoring the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome (TS). The disruptive behavior is most likely due to concurrent attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, present in up to 60% of the cases of TS.  

Tics are defined as swift, abrupt, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). Although considered involuntary, tics can temporarily be voluntarily suppressed. Tics can be primary (e.g., Tourette syndrome, transient motor tics) or secondary (e.g., Wilson disease, post encephalitis). Tics can be further divided into simple and complex tics. This vignette’s inappropriate gesture refers to copropraxia, a complex tic manifested by involuntary obscene/forbidden gestures.    

TS is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and phonic tics that occur during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to disturbance in the cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical (mesolimbic) circuit which results in disinhibition of the limbic system and motor. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition. The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical presentation with onset before age 18.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Echolalia:
Incorrect: Echolalia refers to the involuntary repetition/imitation of another person's vocalizations. 
❌ Echopraxia:
Incorrect: Echopraxia refers to the involuntary repetition/imitation of another person's actions. 
✅ Copropraxia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Coprolalia:
Incorrect: Coprolalia is the involuntary and repetitive use of obscene or socially inappropriate language.
❌ Palilalia :
Incorrect: Palilalia refers to repetition of a word or a phrase with increasing speed.

questions.text: An 85-year-old female is brought to the emergency department due to acute-onset involuntary flinging movements of the right side of her body for the past several hours. The patient has a medical history significant for long-standing hypertension treated with lisinopril but is healthy otherwise. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 155/102 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is orientated and cooperating. Involuntary movements of the proximal and distal muscles on the right side are noted. Motor and sensorial examinations are within normal ranges. Carotid and vertebral artery doppler investigations are normal. Cardiac investigations including echocardiography and electrocardiography are normal. An MRI is obtained, and a diagnosis is made. Aspirin 300 mg and atorvastatin therapies are initiated, and the patient's symptoms resolve gradually in the following 1-day period. This patient’s condition is best characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of hemiballismus likely due to a lacunar infarct of the basal ganglia as a consequence of long-standing hypertension.  

Ballism refers to involuntary movements of the proximal limbs, characterized by large-amplitude, flinging or kicking motions. Ballism is often unilateral (hemiballism), present at rest, and worsened by activity. Traditionally, hemiballism was pathognomonic of a lesion of the contralateral subthalamic nucleus (STN). However, recent evidence suggests that other locations are often involved, including the caudate nucleus, putamen, thalamus, and globus pallidus. Most stroke lesions causing hemichorea/hemiballism seem to involve a common functional network connected to the posterolateral putamen.    
The basal ganglia system is important in regulating movement. Damage or malfunction of these structures disrupts the balance between the indirect and direct pathways in the basal ganglia circuitry, leading to excessive dopaminergic activity. Disruption to the indirect pathway results in loss of inhibition to the globus pallidus, which in turn allows hyperkinetic movements to occur. Chorea, athetosis, and ballism often coexist in the same patient and are considered to be a part of the choreiform spectrum.    

High-yield note: For the purposes of USMLE examinations, keep in mind the association between the subthalamic nucleus and contralateral hemiballismus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dystonia :
Incorrect: Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by sustained, involuntary muscle contractions that result in repetitive movements or an abnormal fixed posture. It may be focal or generalized. Writer's dystonia, also known as writer's cramp is an example of task-specific hand dystonia elicited by writing. However, this patient’s acute onset of rapid, large-amplitude movement favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Myoclonus :
Incorrect: Myoclonus is a brief, involuntary, twitch of a muscle or group of muscles caused by muscular contractions or inhibitions. Muscular contractions manifest as positive myoclonus, while muscular inhibitions produce negative myoclonus such as asterixis. Myoclonus is often described as jerks, shakes, or spasms. However, this patient’s acute onset and resolution of rapid, large-amplitude movement favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Chorea :
Incorrect: Chorea is a type of hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by brief, involuntary and unpredictable contractions of the distal limbs and, less commonly, the face and trunk. The movements seen in chorea are non-patterned, and vary in speed, timing, and direction. Although chorea and ballism are thought to be a part of the same choreiform spectrum, ballismus is characterized by proximal and large amplitude movements, in contrast to the distal, low-amplitude movements of chorea.   
✅ Hemiballism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Athetosis :
Incorrect: Athetosis is a neurological condition characterized by slow, writhing movements of the fingers. The term "choreoathetosis" is often used when chorea and athetosis coexist.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her partner due to rapidly progressive paranoia and personality changes for the past month. The partner first noticed that the patient kept forgetting small things, such as the neighbors’ names, but he began to worry when she started becoming paranoid and accusing him of stealing money from her purse. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient looks anxious. When asked if she knows how to use a pen, the patient takes it and tries to blow air through it. Eye examination reveals bilateral nystagmus. During the examination, the patient exhibits random jerking movement of the legs and kicks the table. A lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following would most likely be found in this patient's cerebrospinal fluid?

choices.text: Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF
Elevated protein levels with normal cell count

questions.solution:
The presence of rapidly progressive (1 month) dementia, memory loss, personality changes and abnormal movements (myoclonus) raises concern for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).  

 CJD belongs to the prion disease family, a group of transmissible, fatal neurodegenerative diseases with long incubation periods and rapid progression once clinical symptoms appear. Prions are small, misfolded, infectious, protein-containing particles (PrPSc) that replicate and replace normal prion proteins (PrPC) over time, resulting in neurotoxicity. CJD can be sporadic (unknown cause) or genetic, due to mutations of the gene encoding the prion protein.    

Diagnosis of CJD involves several different modalities, as follows:

  •  Neuroimaging with MRI is the best initial test for evaluating CJD. Brain MRI excludes other potential causes of dementia and also can suggest CJD as the underlying etiology. On a brain MRI, CJD classically shows enhancement of the basal ganglia and thalamus. 
  •  Periodic sharp wave complexes are the hallmark EEG finding in patients with CJD. The fusion of dendritic membranes of affected neurons result in increased electrotonic coupling and synchronized bursting activity. 
  • Detection of protein 14-3-3 in cerebrospinal fluid is classically seen in patients with CJD; it occurs due to acute neuronal damage.


Option Analysis

✅ 14-3-3 protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF:
Incorrect: Elevated IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF can be seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune neurodegenerative disease characterized by immune-mediated inflammatory demyelination of the central nervous system. Common presenting symptoms include pyramidal signs (e.g., weakness, spasticity), cerebellar syndromes (e.g., diplopia, ataxia), and spinal cord symptoms (e.g., neurogenic bladder, paraparesis).   
❌ S100B protein:
Incorrect: S100B protein is widely used as a measure of glial activity (primarily by astrocytes) or damage. S100B is elevated in cerebrospinal fluid in acute brain injury, such as trauma or stroke, as well as infections. 
❌ Elevated protein levels with normal cell count:
Incorrect: Elevated CSF protein with normal cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation) is characteristic of acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy, the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). The condition is characterized by symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis, facial paralysis (usually bilateral) and respiratory failure. Although the exact cause is unknown, it is often associated with infections (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni).  
❌ Low glucose:
Incorrect: An abnormally low glucose level in the cerebrospinal fluid can indicate possible bacterial infection, fungal infection, a tumor, hypoglycemia, or inflammation of the central nervous system. This patient has no fever or headache, which makes an infection or tumor unlikely.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her sister due to worsening memory loss. The patient has had difficulty balancing her checkbook and has forgotten the names of her grandchildren on several occasions. According to the sister, the patient recently got lost while walking her dog in a park that she has been visiting daily for the past 10 years. She also requires assistance with daily activities, such as housekeeping and purchasing groceries. However, the patient brushes off these concerns, stating “it is merely part of normal aging.” Family history is notable for declining cognitive function in the patient’s father and grandfather when they were in their 70s. Laboratory testing is ordered as part of the work-up. Which of the following will most likely be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient is presenting with significant cognitive impairment and has a family history notable for dementia. She likely has late-onset Alzheimer disease (AD), which can arise due to an increased number of epsilon 4 (ε4) alleles of the apolipoprotein E gene.

AD is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that can be classified into two forms: 1) late-onset sporadic Alzheimer disease, and 2) early-onset familial Alzheimer disease. Late-onset AD makes up the majority of cases and manifests after the age of 65. It is due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Currently, the most firmly established genetic risk factor for late-onset disease is having increased copies of the apolipoprotein E ε4 allele (ApoE4-ε4). Apolipoprotein E is found in the brain and is involved in the removal of amyloid-beta (Aβ). The ApoE4-ε4 isoform, however, is not as efficient at transferring Aβ to the bloodstream, and therefore it causes increased Aβ deposition. Environmental risk factors for late-onset AD include obesity, reduced physical activity, smoking, and history of traumatic brain injury.

In contrast, early-onset AD typically occurs between the ages of 30-65 and makes up 5-10% of cases. It can be due to mutations in the PSEN1 and PSEN2 gene or by having an extra copy of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (e.g. trisomy 21).  

Option Analysis

✅ Apolipoprotein E epsilon 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Apolipoprotein E epsilon 2:
Incorrect: The genetic variant apolipoprotein E epsilon 2 (ApoE2) has actually been shown to be protective against developing Alzheimer disease. Although the exact mechanism is still unclear, it is hypothesized that this ApoE isoform reduces the generation of Aβ plaques and may even aid in the clearance of such plaques.
❌ CAG trinucleotide repeats:
Incorrect: CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions are seen in patients with Huntington disease (HD). Patients typically present with abnormal body movements (chorea), behavioral changes (e.g., aggression, irritability, depression), and dementia. Moreover, patients typically develop symptoms starting in their 40s.
❌ Free serum copper :
Incorrect: Wilson disease is caused by impaired copper excretion into bile and failure to incorporate copper into ceruloplasmin. Copper accumulates in tissues, such as the brain, resulting in neurological symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, Parkinsonism, tremor), behavioral changes (e.g. depression), and cognitive impairment. Patients typically manifest with symptoms in early adulthood, making the diagnosis unlikely in this individual.
❌ Amyloid A protein:
Incorrect: Amyloid A protein (AA amyloidosis) is seen in patients with underlying conditions that cause chronic inflammation, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Patients typically present with widespread amyloid deposition, such as in the kidneys (e.g. nephrotic syndrome), as well as in the liver and spleen, resulting in hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. AA amyloidosis does not typically cause neurological symptoms.
